This place is walking distance from my house (that usually adds a star to my reviews), and has a pretty hip, formal feel while not feeling to stuffy.  There wasnt a huge staff so we might not have gotten the full attention required, but it was never a problem because of the delicious food that we had in front of us.  Appetizers were amazing... The lamb fell right off the bone, the ahi was seared to perfection, and the blackened mahi mahi truly lived up to the idea that its such a great fish they had to name it twice.

Ill be back for sure.  They have many great fish to choose from, prepared many different ways, served with many different sauces.  Thats a whole lot of combos.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Really cute atmosphere with food that is quite good - and the prices make it a tremendous value.
Hmmm.... everything else I would say has already been said (better) by Miriam W.
author: lisa g.

description: Came her for Valentines. It had a nice atmosphere. They had a fixed menu that day and the food was good.
author: Larry V.

description:
Again, it took too long for me to try this place...it's in my hood. Delicious little spot! Warm lighting, intimate setting, fresh seafood. I'm never craving seafood (sushi excluded) but since a certain someone is all Frenched out lately, I said ok.
The number of French sauces available is almost amusing...of course, we couldnt translate, but no bother. Oh, and the creme brulee is about as big as my head, and perfect to share. It's more of an occasion place, but I'll be back.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I love this place. It's a really cute little French bistro tucked away on a residential street. They have a nice variety of fish (and other dishes), prepared numerous ways, with yummy French sauces, at very reasonable prices. They have a great prix fixe menu and also a BYOB (no corkage) night on Wednesdays. 

I accidentally went to their special Bastille Day prix fixe dinner a few years ago - it was outstanding... I keep meaning to do that again, but Bastille Day usually comes and goes without me knowing it.
author: rachel m.

description:
Rotten, rotten service. The kind that ruins your whole night. Rude, impatient, and uneven staff are not guaranteed but a strong possibility. You'll see here that reviews are very hot & cold. Sometimes people come and have a nice meal, good times; other times it's an unmitigated disaster. The food was pretty good and a good value, but nowhere near good enough to save the experience.

There are too many consistently great options in SF to risk your time and money on a roll of the dice at the A.S.S. Grill.
author: Striddy B.

description:
Update:
Returned for a meal of appetizers and had the escargot, scallops gratin, crab cake, seared tuna, and all 3 red wine glasses. The crab cake was large and on delicious bed of stuff, good crab flavor.. i think this year i have eaten more crab then any other. The escargot was nice and meaty and not super garlicky; warning they come out fiery hot and you will scald your tongue; learn from my mistakes. The scallop gratin was good... little too much potato for me but there were chunks of scallop in a crispy creamy crust of potato; very yummie.
I was glad we got to eat the apps for dinner just the right amount of food and all very delicious. Another wonderful evening at Alamo Square.

Orignial Review:
Loved it. At first a little skeptical walking up at 8 to a completely empty restaurant, but we were quickly greeted and seated, whereever we wanted. Our waiter / maitre d / only person other then the chef was very pleasant and congenial. The place is nice and cozy with the daily specials on the chalkboards.
The menu has some great choices and I want to return to have a dinner of just the seafood apps; they all look really delicious.
I had the special salad which was romaine with chunks of bacon and a delicious dressing. The house salad was less interesting with mixed greens and a vinagrette; the special was definitely the winner here.
For the main course i had the peppercorn crusted flank steak on a bed of mashed potatoes and baby bok choy. The steak was cooked well and flavor for medium rare and the portions was decent. The garlic mashed potatoes were perfectly creamy but I didn't want to suffer later with the chunks of whole garlic so i left most of it.
The special was a seared ahi tuna on bed of corn risotto and a sweet salsa which kind of killed the dish. The tuna was perfect with the risotto but the sweet salsa didn't go well.
DESSERT!!! Save room for when they have the warm flourless chocolate cake. AWESOME!! So yummie! A square of decandant dark chocolate in a pool of chocolate and a little dollop of vanilla ice cream.. we licked the plate clean.
I am definitely going back and am going to try all the apps.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
Prix Fixe:  Daily 5:30pm-7:30pm

* 3 course meal= $14.50
1. soup or salad
2. chef's main dish
3. dessert

and it is sooo good!
author: Kate R.

description:
I'm shocked by the number of reviews for this.  I may get in hot water, but I believe their seafood is better prepared than the venerable Hayes Street Grill - am I biased towards French owners?  

Also, the interior decor is kind of romantic.  I'd rate this a good date restaurant.
author: Tim G.

description: Food was excellent, service pretty slow. Verrrrry long delay between appetizers and entrees, but to their credit were perfectly cooked. Had grilled salmon, calamari appetizer, and also a salad on the specials menu, and you probably would be in good shape ordering just about anything here.
author: David P.

description:
Love this little place.

We came here after watching dogs frolic in Alamo Square park - it's a short walk and worth it for sure!

We tried the fixed price menu and were blown away by the quality and quantity of the selections.

Our server was fantastic, accommodating, and friendly.

Their wine list was interesting, we had a red wine that was out of this world - a frog something (know if was a special lot and from France with a price of about $30).

Everything we had, salad, soup, fish and the dessert were spot on.  Oh, the dessert, the quality and quantity of this chocolaty deliciousness could have easily cost half of our total dinner cost.  

Crazy deal for great food, in a cute, cozy little restaurant.
author: LMoo P.

description:
What the F happened to this place? I've been here probably 15 times through the years and have always been impressed by this unassuming neighborhood joint. The waitstaff was always pleasant and the food had the perfect amount of French influence. 

This is no longer the case. The food was extremely over-salted. The meat was grainy, the bread stale, the wine disgusting. To top it all off, the waitstaff were disorganized and rude. The only saving grace was that the salmon was almost as good as it used to be. Can't say I'd ever go back or recommend to anyone I scarcely consider a friend.
author: Michelle D.

description: We met some friends here for dinner on a visit to the city and the food was great.  The seafood was properly cooked and fresh, the veggies delightful.  Casual atmosphere, good prices (we hit it on 1/2 price wine Mondays), and easy close-by parking.  Several fresh fish options nightly with many different choices of preparation. My wife is very discriminating on her fish but she loved the sauteed snapper in Bearnaise sauce.  Mussel appetizer was tasty, so were the fries!
author: Joe R.

description:
It's too bad the quality of the service at Alamo Square Grill doesn't match the quality of the food.

My friends and I had dinner there this weekend, and everyone remarked on how good the food was, especially for the price. We started out with several appetizers -- mussels, crab cake, and fried calamari -- all of which were good. (Well, I'm assuming the calamari was good; it went so fast that I didn't even get to taste it.) One person in our party also had the clam chowder, which he liked very much as well.

For my entre, I had grilled salmon with a garlic parsley butter. The fish was cooked perfectly -- crispy on the outside, delicate on the inside -- and was served on a bed of polenta and roasted vegetables. It was very, very good.

For dessert the table ordered several of the chocolate brownie a la mode. It was warm, gooey, and intensely chocolatey. Excellent.

The interior has a casual, friendly, bistro-like feel. It did get a bit loud, but it was a Saturday night, after all, and the place was hopping.

Now about the service... our server (who I think was also the manager) was very brusque and several times skipped over people when taking our orders for wine, appetizers, food and dessert. For example. upon sitting down, we decided that 2 people in our party were going to order a bottle of wine, while the remaining 5 of us would order single glasses. After placing our order for the bottle and indicating that we wanted two glasses, our server started to leave the table. When I stopped him and explained that the rest of us would be ordering wine by the glass, he acted annoyed. Not cool. Also, after he brought the bottle of wine to our table, he left it there unopened for about 10 minutes while the rest of us who had ordered single glasses stared politely (and longingly) at the glasses of wine sitting before us.

The woman server who pitched in and helped at our table seemed much friendlier. Had she been our server, I think we would have had a much better overall experience.

One saving grace: the gratuity was not included in our check. We tipped accordingly. Had we been forced to pay 18% for sub-standard service, I doubt any of us would make a return visit.

I will definitely go back to Alamo Square Grill, but next time I'll request to sit in a different section.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description: The food here is amazing and the place is very clean. I have no qualms about that. The service was OK. The 2 stars, however, are for the treatment of the kitchen staff which you can see and hear while dining. The owner (I assume) was yelling and berating the cooks and made them redo a dish several times. This superior person spoke to them as if they were the dumbest animals on Earth. The entire restaurant was watching. I felt terrible for the cooks. I cannot contribute or condone that kind of a working atmosphere or treatment of anyone regardless of quality or service.
author: S B M.

description:
I've eaten at the Alamo Square Grill on several occasions (some of them special occasions, & others at random), & it's been one great meal after another. Chef Lance is nothing if not versatile. 

I dropped by with some visiting friends from DC this past weekend, & we were impressed with the staff, the food, & the portions (not too small, but we didn't struggle to walk up the hill when we left).

I'll definitely be back.
author: Pete J.

description:
I took my mom to dinner here. We both choose the prix fixe dinner. The catfish was perfectly prepared and melted in our mouths and came paired with rice and roasted veggies. The desert, which was a floating island was so light and fluffy and I'm sure what clouds might taste like. The food was great and even with the bottle of wine it was not bad cost-wise for a nice dinner in a nice atmosphere. In fact, when I received the bill I was shocked it was so little. I've gone to places with worse food and atmosphere and paid a lot more. 

The only reason that I didn't give it five stars is because we had to wait abnormally long to receive the check, as there were only two people working and the place was packed and then we had to wait long to receive our change, even after reminding the waitress that we were still waiting. 

I will come back again and I hope when I do they have the seafood risotto that was on the chalkboard menu!
author: Roxie J.

description: This place was amazing! The food is very good and the prices are unreal! Had the seafood pasta and the sauteed scallops! Both were excellent! The scallops were cooked perfectly. The seafood pasta had an abundance of actual seafood in it, not just two pieces of shrimp like you end up with at most places. Highly recommend this place
author: Rachel S.

description:
After making a reservation for Valentine's Day at this neighborhood spot only to go home and order pizza after not being seated an hour past our reservation, the bf and I went to give it another shot. 
Service was spotty...or "European", depending on your point of view. 
The swordfish was dry and puny and had a side of rice that can only be described as tasting like Chinese medicinal balls or like what one of those Kathmandu stores smell like (thanks, Emily L.).
And the a good quarter of the steak was fat globules...nobody likes fat globules.
author: Rosalind L.

description:
I was introduced to this place last Sunday by a couple of friends.

The fish dishes are incredible and the sauces are fantastic on them.  I found the service to be efficient, the lighting quite right, and the music selection (Feist at one point) to add to a relaxed mood...parking was ok to find too.....
author: Shaun O.

description:
Sure, it's $2 cheaper than many similar seeming places, but the food is just average. 

Spend the extra $2 and go somewhere good.
author: Jacob L.

description:
This rating would be a ZERO STAR if I could.  I had the worst dinning experience EVER - and really, my bf and I eat out at nearly every meal.  I gave the restaurant an opportunity to somewhat redeem themselves by sending them an email, before I posted a nasty yelp review.  They never responded, so instead of reliving the anger and horror, I'm simply pasting the letter I wrote them as a review:

Dear Andre,
 
I had dinner with my boyfriend at your restaurant on Saturday July 7th.  I eat out at nearly every meal and I'd like to share with you my experience, for two reasons.  First, I'd like for you to take the actions to correct and improve your restaurant - because I love neighborhood restaurants and I think yours is really cute and I want it to do well. Second, it was so bad that every time I think about it I get pissed - and really, I'm a chill person.  I am writing to you because I had the worst experience I've ever had eating out at a restaurant - perhaps, ever.  
 
My bf and I were seated right away.  We ordered our meal, him a tuna in white wine sauce, and me, the steak in medium rare.  We did not receive any service for the next 45 minutes.  No bread.  No drink order.  The busboy brings out our plates and both are cold.  Not even lukewarm - straight COLD.  I eye for service, and get none for a while.  The chef (perhaps you?) sees us and brings bread while asking us how our dishes are - certainly already knowing they are cold.  We send the steak back, and not the fish, not because the fish dish isn't just as cold, but because we needed to EAT something
immediately.  He was about to get a migraine and I was about to pass out from low blood sugar if we didn't eat something right away. Again, there was no service and no bread prior.
 
The chef takes the steak and says "We'll start all over."  When I get the steak, it's the same one, and as you know - you can't re-cook a medium-rare steak.  The meat came out chewy, and hardly medium.  And - he omitted the mixed vegetables, as if the dish would be comped anyway so he didn't even try.  He offered free dessert but we had been at the restaurant for so long - over an hour and a half - that it wasn't worth our time to stay.
 
What was most infuriating about the night actually - was not the food.  
 
My boyfriend left to get the car as the waitress was getting our bill.  The steak was comped - the tuna wasn't.  It bothered me a bit that we'd be paying for the meal because the service and food was THAT bad, but I also felt bad not paying at all.  I place a credit card immediately after I get the bill.  The waitress walks by my table 4 times - without even LOOKING to check if the bill was ready.  The waitress processes to seat a table - and OPEN a bottle of wine for a table of 4!    Like, HELLO!  As if it wasn't bad enough already she completely ignored us for the last hour and a half!  
 
10 minutes pass and my boyfriend comes back into the restaurant to tell me he was parked around the corner... And this is what pisses me off the most...
 
My boyfriend is standing over the table talking to me, and since we had been waiting so long to pay the bill it may seem as if we might take off- cause she KNOWS how BAD her service is...  she stops pouring wine for another table, to REACH across the aisle, UNDER my boyfriend's arm, to GRAB THE BILL.  BUT NOT BECAUSE SHE IS URGENTLY ON HER WAY TO RING THE CARD.  SHE TAKES ANOTHER 5-10 MINUTES TO SEAT A TABLE OF 8 PEOPLE, AND POUR WINE.  WHAT THE FU*K!  And after an hour and a half of completely IGNORING US - the only thing she is quick about is, grabbing the bill before we bail!  
 
This is absolutely the most outrageously rude service I've ever had. 
 
Not only are we not going back, but we are furious and want to tell everyone about it.
author: Lily H.

description:
Five stars for the food. They happened to have trout on the menu when we went in, and I had been wishing they had it on their regular menu. It was cooked perfectly. Best cooked piece of fish I've had in a long time. 

Four stars for service. The credit card machine broke around the time we arrived and because of this we had to wait past our reservation time to be seated, and then 15 minutes for a server. Only then were we told the reason for the delay. Telling us first would have been appreciated. We did receive a taste of soup on the house though, and from that point on things went smoothly.

As an added bonus, we got to watch an awkward first date unfold at the next table. Always a treat.
author: Gus J.

description:
TERRIBLE SERVICE!

My friend had made a reservation, we show up 15 minutes late due to traffic.  We walk in and my friend talks to who seems to be dealing with the seating.  He pretty much yells at my friend for being late and says "well good thing you showed up now cause I was just about to give up your table".

I have worked service before and yes it's annoying when people show up late for a reservation, but you do not talk to your guests like that.  So whatever, we sit down.  My friend seems pretty flustered abou the situation but decides to deal with it. 

2 minutes - We get ice water.

10 minutes - We get our menus (yeah we didn't even get menus when we where seated)

25 minutes - We decide to leave cause the server NEVER came over to say anything to us at all.  We just sat.... with our waters and menus.  

I'm sorry, but there is no excuse for sitting in a resturant for that long without getting any sort of communication from your server.  Tell me that you are really busy and will be with me shortly at least!  I'm a very patient person, but I couldn't take it anymore.

I put my jacket on, tell the table we need to spilt because this is just terrible.  

The waiter asks when we get up, "Are you leaving?"

Thanks for noticing us now!

I exchanged some words with the server and he was not very appolagetic at all for pretty much ignoring us and was just telling us to sit back down and he will serve us.  Sorry buddy already gave you close to a half an hour to serve us.  

It's been a really long time since I have recived such bad service.  But if you like being ignored this is a perfect place for you.
author: Shikhiu I.

description:
It's a shame since I really wanted to like this place because it was near my old apartment and I always thought it'd be good.

But alas, it's really not all I dreamed it would be. Yet another dining experience brought down by high expectations, soggy "over-ripe" mussels (tsk tsk--see The Public for good mussels http://www.yelp.com/biz/k1qsMESfLoAbCW270SunWw), overly salty french fries, and fruit tarts served on stale pastry. Boo.

My friends had the fish dishes which they seemed to enjoy. I had the gnocchi which wasn't horrible. But oh, the mediocrity of it all. If you insist on eating here, order the fish (it's a seafood grill, so at least they do that well) and avoid everything else.
author: Viv C.

description:
Want fish? Come here! Choose your fish, the style of cooking and the preparation/sauce. 

I had Sea Bass, sauteed, Provencale style. The side vegetables included carrots and summer squash, that were carefully cooked to maximize delicious fresh flavors. I enjoyed them! The fish was delicious! Flaky, moist, flavorful and delightful overall. 

Of course there's a wine list and it's not bad. The service was personable and present. Wine glasses were monitored and the patrons are greeted with friendly smiles.

Their French bread is served with a pesto dipping sauce. Salad is good. Dessert is also good, though they were out of Profiteroles au Chocolat, much to my disappointment. Instead we enjoyed Almond Floating Islands, which were poofs of meringue in an almond sauce with strawberry slices arranged around the plate with a sprig of mint and berry coulis. It was good and surprisingly light!
author: Audra K.

description:
Very reasonably priced seafood place from the people who brought you Papa Toby's.  We were looking for a nice, quiet spot where we could get some fresh fish at a reasonable price without having to dress up.  And that is exactly what we got.   But we had no idea how lovely and romantic it would be inside.  Great place to bring a date.

They don't have too much of a menu.  Its mostly a list of fish, a list of ways to prepare it, and a list of sauces.  Everything was well prepared and tasty.  We will definitely be back.
author: Steve S.

description:
This is my favorite rest in the city to bring out of town guests who want fish:
- Is the quintessential san Francisco neighborhood restaurant
- The menu is simple
- The food is fantastic
- The price is very reasonable.  
- Don't ignore the veggie option(s) they are fantastic.  

Must do with guests and as frequently as possible.
author: Johnny C.

description:
This became an instant favorite of mine. Nestled behind Alamo Square is a delightful restaurant that's cozy, romantic, and delicious. They have a wide variety of daily specials and the servers couldn't be more pleasant. The seared ahi tuna is heavenly- a must try. 

Wednesday night is has no corkage fee, so bring a bottle and one of your nearest and dearest. Also an excellent place for a date, especially a first date....and save room for dessert!
author: Beth M.

description:
The food is great here and so reasonably priced.  I havne't been able to figure out a pattern on when this place is busy or empty, I think it's just blind luck.  Anyway, if you don't have a reservation you could possibly end up waiting a long time for a table (outside because there's not much room inside).

I only gave it 4 stars because as others have said, the service kind of sucks.  If you expect it to be slow and get a bottle of wine, you should have a delightful evening.
author: Jackie A.

description:
mmmmm delicious fish. they have about 4 or 5 fish specials every night, and you can cook it the way you want (grill, poach, blacken , etc) and sauce it the way you want  (white sauces or red sauces, w/ wine, capers, etc) 

Its really fresh and tasty and at a great price... does it get any better? wish place was bigger,  other than that, great low key, relaxed place to enjoy seafood and wine! 

get desert at bi-rite though.... mmmmm creamery.
author: Matthew B.

description:
The reason I created a Yelp account.  

Food: good
Service:  Horrible!!! (at least for groups)

I went there with a group of 8 for my friend's Going Away party.  The first 90% of the meal was great.  When it was clear I wasn't much of a fish guy, the waiter politely suggested a better way to prepare my fish.  I was glad I took his opinion bc the food was great.   

The last 10%: BAD
As expected the bill was steep (8 people + bottles of wine).  So since none of us carried $60+ in cash we split it evenly on like 5 cards.  When the waiter came by to pick up the check he was obviously annoyed.  He said that it might take a minute before he could ring us up.  No biggie.  WRONG!  He went around and checked on every table, chatting it up with a few, and even ringing up multiple other bills.  The worst part was since we were a group +6, tip was included - he had us by the balls.  

27min later (yes I timed it) he finally got to our bill.  What he did next just pissed me off.  Instead just taking out the cards and swiping, he indignantly poured out the cards onto the register.  

Thank god for yelp otherwise I'd have no power.
author: Nolan R.

description:
Oh yes, a good seafood place and in my neighborhood no less!  Granted, I didn't stay to eat in the restaurant but I had some very tasty crab cakes with polenta and a grilled salmon, cooked up tender with bearnaise.  Mmm... 

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Despite knowing that I'll be lambasted by friends and foodies alike, I stand by an honest review. This restaurant is a forced nice evening. The food is, of course, the star of the show here. Good fish dishes, prepared to taste. Still, it's only 'okay'. 
For it's tiny size, however, the service is painful. In my visits the staff has been forgetful, slow to serve, bring the bill without checking the table, and jump over 'the line' of many no-no's for a nice restaurant.
There are other restaurants that need visiting.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
The good:  nice space, a block & 1/2 from my apartment, fresh fish, pretty good food though nothing to write home about.  Great prices.

The bad:  OMG what everyone says about service is true - it sucks.  But we didn't experience the hateful ignoring service everyone talks about, just the stupidest slowest wait staff on earth.

The ugly:  ok, me being super critical - how do places like this survive?  It's not like there aren't a bundle of better places 4 blocks away down Hayes St.  That being said, and color me 2-faced, but I would return here on a night when my hubby was out of town, I was too tired to walk any further, and I had a good book to read during the 30 minute lulls in service.  Free corkage nite is a great deal...
author: Allison K.

description: This is one of the best kept secrets of San Francisco.  The best seafood and the best romantic date place in the city.  It's always about 3/4 full.  It's low-key but classy, with great fish, wine, and crabcakes.  This is one of those places that shows you really know the city and all it has to offer.
author: Ben S.

description:
Flat as a Flounder  (2.5 stars)

A neighborhood spot with a charming interior and reasonable prices but mediocre food and indifferent service.  Dinner for two with wine around $80.  (But there is a bargain $15 3-course prix fixe before 7 pm)  Go back?  In no rush.

Place/Service.  Cozy bistro setting with clever use of mirrors; chalk board specials; tight table spacing; warm decor.  We sat for more than a few minutes before our order was taken or our existence acknowledged.  Not sure why the vibe was not nearly as friendly as the appearance of the place.  

Food/Wine.  Again, the potential failed to deliver.  The beet salad was bland in flavor and texture.  Nice concept to have the choice of preparation and sauce for the various fish of the day.  Unfortunately, the grilled trout with bearnaise sauce which should have been a classic reminded me of something from a college cafeteria; the mahi special looked nice but lacking in flavor.  Luckily, a bottle of white Rhone soothed the palate.
author: Yan L.

description: We had a group of seven so we were able to explore the menu pretty well.  The appetizers of fried calamari and mussels (both white wine and chorizo styles) were excellent, but we had one person in our group who did not eat seafood so it would have been nice if there was something like a bruschetta or mushrooms on the menu.  It worked out OK,  however, since she ended up eating a lot of the French fries that came with the mussels.  The chicken worked out well as an entre for this person.  (There is a excellent rib eye steak on the menu as well.)  The vegetarian plat du jour didn't sound that appealing.  Other entries selected included sautéed trout, grilled mahi-mahi, grilled salmon and the seared Ahi tuna special.  It was all very good.  We had some good, reasonably priced wines with dinner - the house Sauvignon Blanc from the Loire Valley, a Vouvray Chenin Blanc and a J. Lohr Pinot Noir (CA).  Desserts were all good, but my favorite was the Crème Brulee by far.  Andre took good care of us, but he was stretched pretty thin.  His bus person seemed inexperienced as she was asked for an extra plate and more water but never came back with them.  Nearly everyone's water glass was empty when Andre responded to our request for more water.  We will be back.
author: Tim M.

description:
The restaurant itself is very cute and charming looking and the prices are reasonable.  

Our waiter seemed fine to me but service in general  was slow for my taste.  It took forever to get water refills and after our order was taken, it took a while for the main course to come out.  But because that may have had to do with the fact that my dinner companions got there early and ordered appetizers a half hour before me, I think they tried to stagger the food when I ordered another appetizer and I can't blame them for that.

I liked that there was no corkage fee but I was disappointed by my fish.  I had the mahi mahi grilled with garlic and parsley butter.  The fish was dry, even though the portion was decent.  

For dessert, I shared the profiteroles.  They were crunchier than I expected so I wouldn't order it again.

Overall, if you're in the neighborhood, it's fine but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there again.
author: Seong P.

description:
Soon to be unemployed and my good friend takes me out to get dinner... hes lazy and we ALWAYS go out in his hood... do I mind? Hell no! He lives in Alamo Square which means there are GREAT restaurants within walking distance to his place... CASE AND POINT!

Bottle of white wine... fabulous. Remember the name of it.. no because of the several glasses we had prior to dinner.

Apps. Mussels and Calamari. Both were fantastic. If I had to choose one of the other it would be the mussels. Not too fishy and and had an amazing broth to dip the bread in after.

Dinner: This was fun... Choose a fish and then choose how it is prepared and with what sauce. I got the Trout sauteed with the Beurre Blanc and my friend got the Red Snapper blackened with the Bearnaise. We had a fork fight trying to steal each others fish b/c both were fantastic

Desert: OK here is where I had some fun. On the chalkboard it said "Pineapple Upside Down Cake" I probably said pineapple upside down cake about 30 times and forced ourselves to eat the cake with full bellies. HOT DAMN GREAT CHOICE!

Great place for a little romance and its small to keep it intimate. Too bad it wasn't a date but if it was ... watch out. Lost a star because service is slow. They had on guy working a packed restaurant. Granted once we ordered the food came extremely fast.
author: Nancy B.

description: Hidden. Cozy. Charming. Great food. Good prices. Always easy to talk/hear. Definitely a solid neighborhood spot where you don't have a line of 40 hipsters out the door and fight to get a table. Reservations are recommended. Good for a first date and a romantic walk to Alamo Square after.
author: SF I.

description: It is simple - the owner cares about his guests, and price/performance is excellent. Many restaurants have "forgotten" how to do crab cakes with crab meat, not this one. Fish courses are balanced and deserts deliver. You will not get gigantic portions, you will get good food. Service personnel are friendly and spend time with guests. All together, warm recommendation.
author: Admir A.

description:
I went to Alamo Square Seafood Grill for the first time this week and had the Bouillabaisse. It was a delicious meal, and we plan to go back.

It's also got a great neighborhood vibe. It's a nice bistro ambiance right around the corner from Alamo Square Park.
author: Shanan D.

description:
Ok I'm giving this a 3 star for food and the extra 1 star for service/ambiance.  Went here tonight for my friend's birthday dinner - he pass by it daily on the 22 bus.  Great service!  Walked in early and they walked me straight to our table while I waited brought me water.  

Calamari was crispy and tasty - with this aioli sauce. Escargots was ok - garlic parsley butter (very garlicky) - guess I like mine with more melted butter and garlic.  Yes I am definitely going back because I made the mistake of ordering the NY Steak with Bearnaise sauce more so because I loved this sauce after having it once at a NY restaurant - but it wasn't the same (or as good) so shoulda stuck with the fish. 

I'm not a Zin girl (if you've read my review you know I am a Cab lover) but this one we tried was really good - full, not too fruity, strong for a Zin.  It's called Dashe 2006 Zinfandel from Dry Creek Valley for only ($30ish I believed).  They do have decent wine prices - nothing over $55 for a bottle. 

Oh Tip: Wednesday is FREE cockage fee. Normally about $12.00 per bottle with 2 bottles mininum.  Good deal.
author: Lily W.

description: This is a great little spot. Is it the best seafood I've ever had? Nah. But is it damn good? Yep! Add a VERY reasonable price, and you've got a place that I'm happy to go back to again!
author: Kevin H.

description:
My favorite neighborhood spot!!! Todd is the man. Service is great for what he has to deal with...all those unruly customers!

If you want a much more reasonably priced meal with equal or better quality than Hayes Street Grill - give Alamo Square Grill a try! And you don't get all of those old stuffy farts that frequent the ballet in there!!!
author: Scott N.

description: Monday evening. The place still has a couple of free tables (so yeah, not completely full). Host/waiter is serious according to my husband. Plain rude if you ask me. We want the $25 Pinot, they only have the $85 one, so we stick with a $35 Merlot. Food takes one hour to arrive, rice is cold, veggies are tasty, tuna is ok, but far from great. We order dessert, after another 25 of wait we just cancel it and order the check, 10 minutes later my husband goes to the bar to pay because the check never came. We live only 3 blocks away and don't plan on going back...
author: Tatiana C.

description:
We were headed to the city last minute and picked this restaurant since all our other choices were filled up.  We are glad we did as we liked it very much. Although not for everybody, the clientele they do serve seem very happy to be there.

This is a low key, neighborhood restaurant that serves delicious fish at amazingly affordable prices.  I was at a table of four picky eaters and we each ordered a different fish/sauce and were all equally pleased with our dinners.

The parking is awful of course and being a neighborhood place, there is no fast way to get there if you don't live in the neighborhood other than to slog through the stop lights. 

The wine list is poor and I would highly recommend bringing your own as they have a very modest corkage fee ($12) and thankfully they don't make you feel bad for bringing your own wine like some restaurants do.

We would definitely go back to Alamo Square and would recommend it to friends looking for  a low key and pleasant dinner out.
author: Kristine H.

description:
First off, this place is literally directly under my apartment.  At first I was skeptical about moving in right about a seafood grill.  I imagined that I'd have rotting fish stench wafting up to my apartment from the trash bins in back.  Luckily, this hasn't been the case at all.  So far I've only had excellent food smells drifting up.  

It's not the nicest restaurant in SF, but if you want good seafood for a fraction of the price you'd pay elsewhere it seems to be a good choice.  I also recommend paying attention to the specials and the prix fixe menu.  I've had the best luck with them.

EDIT 4/11:  In the last month or so they got a new server.  He's much better than the guy who used to work here.  The food actually comes out in a timely manner, he always lets me taste a couple of wines before I pick, and he's really funny and kinda cute (and not in a bitchy, trying to be French way).
author: Katie S.

description:
The new manager of this place is a real jerk. I used to love the French guy--he looked like a cirque de soliel character, was charming and sweet, and really took care of the customers.

The new guy has been there since January and treats the staff and customers terribly. My last visit  we went through 3 bottles of wine before our entrees came ou, cold--there were four of us and we are NOT big drinkers.Then, the manager apologized for cold food by blaming it on the chefs--but wait a minute, chefs don't make cold food, do they?

Hopefully "new guy with the shark tooth" figures things out soon. We gave Alamo "another chance" tonight, and the place was empty. 

It's disappointing to see a great neighborhood gem really go downhill.
author: jodes l.

description:
I have been to Alamo Square Seafood Grill twice now. 

The first time I was with a group of out of town visitors. Great food, horrible service. She got butter on my shirt, she dropped bread in my lap, and she ignored us for 15-20 minutes at a stretch.  This wouldn't have bothered me that much, except that she didn't seem to care at all. The deep fryer was down so there were no fries, but she forgot to mention it until I ordered. 

The food however was great. I had a NY Steak. Perfectly cooked, with a great sauce and fantastic potatoes. The people I was with all had the Snapper, and there wasn't a bite left on the plate. The GF and I shared a one of the best pieces of tiramisu we'd ever had. 

The next day we complained to the manager, and  to our surprise, he comped us a second meal. 

On our second trip, the service was much, much better. At times a little slow , but she was apologetic about it (different waitress, there is only one a night), and very pleasant. Our server also knew all the dishes very well. We found out that there is only one server on duty at a time, so they can get a backed up. 

We repeated the same entrees. The steak was great again, this time it was served with frites, which where crispy and hot,  but a little too salted. My GF's snapper was also too salty, but still good. I the soup of the day, which was potato and corn with cream and blue cheese. Fantastic. The GF got the mussel appetizer. The mussels were good, but not great (a few of them were bitter, perhaps they're going out of season?) but the broth they were served in was amazing. The GF was dipping the good bread they serve into it to get it all. Dessert was a good hot chocolate cake with ice cream. My GF had a lemon cheesecake and ginger snap crust. The cheesecake was not as smooth as some places, but the flavor was there. 

Good food, great prices, so-so service. I will be back!
author: Chuck K.

description:
I used to live right around the corner from this place, and I would eat here at least a couple of times a month.  Great seafood, good service and a very intimate setting (sometimes it can be kinda crowded).   While the seafood is top notch, sometimes the side-dishes are a little...ummm...uninspired.  I mean sometimes they're great, but a few times I went there and it seemed like they were trying something new, and it wasn't so great.  But the fish alone is worth the visit.

Make sure you order the crab cake appetizer, they're some of the best I've had.

Wednesday nights are BYOB night (no corkage)!!!
author: Mark G.

description: I came here for my birthday dinner. We were promptly seated and our drink orders were quickly taken. We wanted champagne but they were out of it that night.  Our waitress was very friendly, but over worked.  After our initial drinks we were never offered more; our water was refilled one time.  The restaurant is small and cozy, and once it fills up it is very tight. The patrons have to cooperate to get into the seats and allow the wait staff to deliver food.  All of our food was excellent.  I had calamari and mushroom soup to start and Scallops for the entrée.  The only complaint amongst my companions were the Brussel sprouts that were not cooked enough--they were too hard to get a fork into them, so they were the only thing left on our three plates.  We didn't stay here for dessert but decided to go over to BiRite for some ice cream.
author: Herschell L.

description: The food was very good and the prices were reasonable.  The atmosphere is very charming, but the service was miserable the night we were there.  They seemed to be understaffed and each request was made at least three times before we received an additional wine glass, an additional bottle of wine, and then a glass of wine.  I would have rated higher if the service was better.
author: Donna L.

description:
Absolutely enjoyed it on a date with my girlfriend.

I like the choice of picking your fish, the four ways you want it cooked and the six choices of sauce.  Great help from our waiter on selecting the sauce with red snapper.

We shared the pear tart and creme caramel were a nice size and amazing.
author: Stephen W.

description:
A great neighborhood restaurant and ideal for taking maybe a first date or someone you want to impress with your knowledge of local dining.  Prices are much lower than you would expect to pay are equally fancy places, cozy setting with less tables meaning better service, intimate lighting and delicious, unique food.  No need for a suit jacket but leave that Greatful Dead t-shirt at home, you no class bum.

A few tips for ordering: 
- Order seafood!  This is their specialty and other dishes are sub-par.
- Mid-range priced wines are the way to go here.  Great cabernet!
- Try to arrive early for the $12.50 pre-fixe.  6pm - 8pm.  w00t!!

UPDATE-

I recently returned and had a much worse experience.  Slow service, incredibly over salted fish and their prices have gone up while the menu has shrunk.  I would not return.
author: Ryder M.

description:
This place turned out to be a pretty solid disappointment. Since I live so close, I was really hoping to have a good experience here. I've been there twice. Here's what went down.

Trip 1: I was on a date. After sitting down and waiting a few minutes, I noticed a cockroach walking RIGHT behind my head. I nearly lept from the table, but didn't want to make a big deal. Ya know, these things can happen and given that I'd yet to accurately judge the service and food, I wanted to give the place the benefit of the doubt. I quietly told the waiter about the cockroach and he seriously shrugged it off like it was no big deal. He went over and grabbed the cockroach but was FAR from apologetic. Although we were very uncomfortable, we decided to stay. The food was average at best. Everything was VERY salty and the prices were way too high for such average food. The service was sub-par and we left disappointed.

Trip 2: About six months later, my girlfriend and I (different girl) were sitting in apartment starving one night and I figured I'd give this place another shot. We had the same waiter that I'd had about six months prior and this time he was quite rude. He has an arrogance about him that is very offputting. He's not necessarily a "jerk" per-se, but he has a nonchalance attitude that makes you think you're imposing on him. 

I can't even recall what I ordered, but when I took my first bite I almost broke a tooth. I spit out a pebble onto the table and was furious. Given that this was somewhat of a special night for the lady and I, I didn't want to make a big deal. I proceeded to eat my meal cautiously and my girifriend, whose dish was served cold, ate without complaint.

We both agreed that we would never ever go back to this place.

Food: C-
Atmosphere: B-
Service: D
author: K F.

description:
This is on my top 5 for San Fran. Get their fish special, you pick the fish of the night usually 4 choices, the way it is cooked and the sauce. My favorite is when the have Ahi, I get it sauteed with Beurre Blanc. The wine is very reasonably priced and they have a great selection. The apps are awesome (crab cakes with lobster love) and everything here is so so inexpensive, especially for the quality. 
We went with my family when they were visiting, we each (4 of us) had an appetizer, entree, shared 2 desserts and had a bottle of wine and dessert drinks...and under $120. Don't forget Wednesday is BYOB NO CORKAGE!  Plus my parents loved it so much they cancelled our reservations the next night at House of Prime Rib because they wanted to go back!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
This is my new favorite Wednesday night eatery. 

Not only is there no corkage fee (2 bottle maximum) but you can choose what type of fish you'd like and how you would like it prepared all for 14 bucks - it's the best deal I've found lately in the city!

The night I went we had grilled tuna with green peppercorn sauce - amazing! I can't wait to return!
author: Summer C.

description:
- food: very good
- atmosphere: cozy and neighborhood-y
- price: reasonable
- staff: fine

additional info:
- we're going back
author: J. B.

description: Great little seafood restaurant around the corner from the Painted Ladies  houses on Alamo Square. They serve 4 kinds of fish nightly with a choice of 4 preparations and choice of 4 sauces. I had red snapper, blackened with berre blanc sauce and it was delicious. My brother had the salmon grilled with a tomatoe sauce and didn't like it as much. I would stick with the wine based sauces. It's very small place( about 8-10 tables) and with a limited menu but the food was very good.
author: Barbara E.

description: Every time we eat here, I don't know why we don't go here more often.  It's in our neighborhood and it's a perfect neighborhood spot.  Quaint spot, pleasant service, and really tasty food at excellent prices.  You also can't beat their 1/2 price bottle of wine night on Mondays!  If you live close by, or even across town and are looking for a cute little place for dinner, this is a great option.
author: Andrew B.

description: Neighborhood gem. Excellent, *small* restaurant. The menu is simple, but everything is done well, and priced VERY reasonably. I most recently had the scallops special ($18, I think) and it was terrific. Appetizer, two entrees, a nice wine, and a shared dessert will run you ~$100. The servers know their menu and their wine list, and we've had a lot of fun bouncing requests off them. The only caveat (and not worth deducting a star) is that the restaurant fills easily, and noise bounces everywhere. Nice, easy-going, grown-up crowd. Highly recommend.
author: Miss M.

description:
When I think of Alamo Square, it reminds me not of the park next door to this restaurant, but of the Alamo in San Antonio, TX, because I lived in Houston for three years. So it's hard for me to associate this name with French cuisine. But not only is the food French, it's very good French, too.  

My friends and I went on BYOB night (Wednesday) and while I would have preferred a cute French waitress, the pouty guy who took care of us in an extremely efficient manner was just as authentic. The mussels we got as appetizers were divine, and all three of us had different sauces, beurre blanc, bearnaise and a green pepper sauce, which were rich and flavorful as sauces should be. The creme brulee a l'orange was good, though a little too tangeriney.  

Of  course, what made the evening magical was the three bottles of wine we had, the winner of the evening being a Toscana, Villa Antinori, which is on Wine.com 's under-20-over-90 list. 

It is definitely great value for money.
author: Sameer S.

description:
This place is good; not spectacular, but spectacularly consistent.   If you are looking for an affordable French Bistro style seafood fix in the neighborhood then this is the place to go.   Choose your fish, choose the style you want it cooked, choose your sauce and you are good to go. 

Wednesday is no corkage making this a good deal, particularly since their wine list is not that great.
author: Jim Z.

description:
In sum, this is an above average restaurant which could easily move into the exceptional area with a few minor changes.

I will start with the bad so I can end on a positive note:  Alamo Square needs to overhaul their white wine list immediately. We tried four and all were horrible, not bad, they were horrible. I would stay away from the Baby Field Greens & Fines Herbes Salad. [sic] Look, if my girlfriend, who's idea of cooking is boiling water for ramen noodles, can make a better salad than you then you didn't try hard enough. It was not a salad at all. It looked like someone took a handful of mixed greens from a bag of greens purchased at Safeway and added four, yes we counted, four pieces of radish.  To make things worse, server 0001 was not at all apologetic when we mentioned the chef's lack of imagination relative to the salad and said "we have other salads on the menu but you ordered mixed greens and that is what you got." We left fifteen percent anyway because he was a pretty nice guy and gave honest opinions on menu choices.  Come on Alamo chef, most people feel that a mixed greens salad would come with a slice of tomato or a cumber. Spend a dollar on a salad, will you. 

The good far outweighs the bad.  I like the off-the-beaten-path location. The restaurant has a nice quaint feel and it clearly has lots of regulars. The steamed mussels were very good. The swordfish was excellent but if you can substitute anything for the uninspired unflavored vegetables that accompany it do it! The Mediterranean Fish Soup is similar to boulibase but not quite as thick but is a real bargain at $14.75. The salmon was better than average, the bread pudding really good and the flourless chocolate cake was excellent but on the small side.

I will return but the next time I will go on a Wednesday night when you can bring your own wine and not pay a corkage fee and order from the prix fixe menu. I think the overall  three and a half star rating is right on target.
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
Alamo Square Seafood Grill in San Francisco's Hayes Valley is a quaint Parisian style cafe tucked away between Victorian homes on Fillmore Street. It's a popular neighborhood spot that's been open for 9 years. The restaurant is tastefully decorated and very small, about 10-15 tables total with no formal bar. The General Manager, Andre, is a highlight of the place. His garish French attitude is fun and he says everything with a smile while God knows what he is thinking in his head. He adds quite a bit to the charm and amusement to the place. 

The menu is proportionate to the restaurant, small but good. It is almost entirely seafood except for three land lover dishes: a rib eye, a chicken and a vegetarian dish. Fish is their speciality, with few shellfish choices, so you really need to like fish fish to enjoy your meal here. I had the blackened sole with tomatoes, capers, olives and my mother the grilled salmon with bearnaise white wine, shallots and tarragon hollandaise. Both fish dishes were delicious. My fiance asked Andre what he would recommend and in fine French fashion he looks him over and said, "you will have the sauteed salmon with beurre blanc" and quickly scribbled it down on his pad. We all called out "no!"  as he was looking for one of the land lover dishes and not fish, but we all liked his enthusiasm. His rib eye turned out to be delicious with its yummy truffle butter and pmme frites (french fries). We had the creme brulee for dessert and it was divine but the crust wasn't hardened enough and I wasn't able to get that cracking sound when I dove in for my first bite.

Alamo Square Seafood is a delicious under recognized restaurant. Its a neighborhood favorite but should also be a San Francisco landmark. It's got everything you need on a night out on the city, a little attitude, quaint atmosphere and delicious fresh seafood. Plus they have 1/2 wine on Mondays and no corkage fees on Wednesdays!
author: Alice S.

description:
Update 11-5-06

I really like this place but the last 2 times I went (in the past 3 weeks) I was really disappointed in my food.  One time I ordered the snapper and it seemed dry and they hardly put any sauce on it.  The other time I ordered the salmon.  The salmon was actually great but they put this gross sweet sauce on it that ruined it.  It also took forever to get the bill and change.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
This is a great date restaurant.  The atmosphere is very cozy and intimate, yet loud enough so you don't feel that people are listening to your conversation.  

I had the salmon and my boyfriend had the snapper.  Delicious!  My mouth is watering just thinking out it!  I like that you can pick the way you want your fish prepared and also which sauce to go with it.  Make sure to save room for the tiramisu.  

It is a very busy place.  The service is great and friendly but it can be a little slow at times.  The only downside was that our table was close to the door and the main pathway of the restaurant and my chair was bumped all night long :(
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description:
This is my new neighborhood. And this is my new neighborhood seafood place. I have never had a seafood place ever- but I now have one.
I had the most delightful time here. 
Bottle of wine- watching my D beach try and eat snails...oh the joy.
It was truley endearing -seeing him try so hard to get a small piece of black snail.
I had the great special. D Beach had a brillant blackened fish with Bure Blanc sauce.
It was all great.. 
The one thing is that there is only one server- and he is the host also.
There is a bus girl, but she seemed dreamily wandering about.
Although picked up our dishes when we were finished.
The chef was visible and seemed to be having a great time- which in turn made me have a beter time.
Plus seeing a real life genius get stumped by snails was awesimo.
author: shannon t.

description:
First off I'm a pretty positive person so this review is not in character but...

RUN AWAY RUN AWAY

First I sat in a folding chair that was too low for the table. I felt like a little kid sitting at the big person table. I agree with Justin the host is a wad, he came to the table and asked what we wanted with out explaining what was the special fishes of the day were.  Then got snotty when we asked...  major wad.  

Food: Stop at the appetizers we split the calamari and mussels which were both pretty good.  The main course took forever to come well over a half an hour.  Finally when it got to the table it was wrong... But because it was so LOUD. I couldn't talk to our server to explain and just took it.  So mine grilled salmon was under cooked and my friends was over cooked.  I think they messed up my dish and while they rushed to redo mine, my friends got over done.  How do you screw up grilled salmon anyway??  None of us finished our meals and left. 

So to recap JUST DON'T GO!! Go to MacDonald and have a Fish Fillet sandwich it will probably be better and no wad!!
author: Kevin C.

description:
Not expecting perfection, we went anyways - The calamari was delivered COLD and awful...We considered sending it back, but were afraid that we would get even poorer service with the rest of the meal.

The rest of the food was ---- ok...

Not going back - even though the location is pretty good for those hitting a show at the Fillmore, Yoshi's or the Boom Boom Room.
author: larry n.

description:
No corkage on Wednesday...which is pretty awesome.
But the food was just eh. Escargo was yummy, but a little too greasy
My man's ahi and mashed potatoes came out cold
My snapper was a little over cooked and had a provensal sauce that kinda tasted like it was out of a can
The flour-less chocolate cake was decent, but not really great
Price wise, I thought they were reasonable.
Service was great. When the server came over and asked how we were I told her about the cold fish and taters. She gave us desert for free. I opted for a glass of their tawny port as my desert, and I am glad I did. Alcohol is always a better option.

So, not sure I would go back, pretty unlikely, especially since it is around the corner from my house.
author: Sara A.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco that I dearly miss. We started going there around when it first opened. Great vibe and great food. It was so convenient  considering we lived right around the corner. Several years later, Andre the owner catered our wedding at the Arch Bishops Mansion around the corner. I came back the other night with wife and now child. Sorry we missed you Andre, but it was still fantastic. Keep up the good work.
author: Scott M.

description:
Alamo Square is in this great little neighborhood that doesn't have too many other restaurants within the 2-3 block radius, therefore it's charm.  Also, it has/had the BYOB on Wednesday nights with the prix fixe dinner, which really rocks and has people slamming in there, especially on hot summer nights when no one wants to be indoors.  

The cutesy, homey neighborhood feel makes it welcoming, but there are many other things that do not.  No. 1, as everyone mentions  here, the attitude.  OK, we all know gay restaurants that don't like hetero clients, but I get the impression that this is in a neighborhood that's mixed, and therefore, should have mixed clientele.  No. 2, I usually like a gay atmosphere, but this place has gotten on my nerves too often.  No. 3, Make no mistake about it, this is NOT French attitude, but "I'm too busy for the likes of you," attitude.

I also don't like feeling I have to give guys the evil eye when scoping out my bf; especially the servers.  Yeah, hey, I know he's hotter than July, that's why I'm with him, but he likes fresh fish to eat on his plate and his bed!  Leave my man alone beeatch!  

Food's average and reasonably priced.  I like the fish, but the cooking's hit and miss -- flavoring's a little sophomoric.  As anyone can guess, I'm big on texture and Alamo is missing in this area.  The desserts are okay, and overall, I'd go back if I didn't want to leave the neighborhood, but I'm leaving the hot boyfriend at home--you should too!  :o)
author: A W.

description:
If I were a fish, I would willingly throw myself into the net so I could have the pleasure of being cooked at Alamo Square.

Prix fix 3-course dinners for $14.50.

Frankly, that's enough to make anything taste pretty spectacular.

(The whole candlelit atmosphere ain't so bad, neither.)
author: Anna H.

description: This place definitely has sort of a somebody's living room feel which I really liked, and it was quiet which was great for our group. The atmosphere is definitely top notch. The good was quite good but not great. We all got the prix fixe (cauliflower soup or salad, filet, and floating island). The soup was good, the salad was a little heavy on the parsley with a very basic dressing, the filet (while you could tell it was a good piece of meat) was very thin, a little overcooked and underseasoned (no S&P on the tables) but the accompaniments were very good. The highlight of the meal was the bread and amazing dipping sauce and the floating island desert which was very unique and delicious. All around a very good experience and for $15 it's a great value.
author: M L.

description:
What is not to love about a charming, local place that offers a prix fix menu for under $15?

Get here early for this deal, however,as they do fill up.
author: Matthew R.

description:
I came here on a Monday night, so you know it wasn't very busy. My companion and I had a nice window seat with some pillows to add to our comfort. The menu had so many great items to chose from that I could not pick something. I had my waiter pick for me- I had the fish of the day- broiled Mahi Mahi covered in some herbs (I can't remember what they were) but it was ooh SOOO GOOD! It came with a delicious tomato risotto that I could barely stop eating, and sauteed spinach. Ah. I saved enough for leftovers and I had an awesome lunch the next day! YUM! 

My friend had roasted chicken with polenta and spinach. She said her dish was wonderful and delicious, too. 

I thought the restaurant was cute, our waiter was patient, nice, helpful and funny.  It's a small place so I can see how it would be loud on a busy night. 
Go on a Monday :)
author: Amy J.

description:
Aight, so I had the grilled snapper. Let me tell you, this place serves up some delicious fish...steaks. Yeah, they're plump, large, and very fresh. The sides are good, too.

The place loses a star because it's kinda small. Which I suppose could be a pro if you were into a more intimate setting. Me, I don't like feeling so close to the kitchen regardless where I'm at.

Justmuhthang.
author: Josh B.

description: I love that I can get fish prepared virtually any way that I want here.  Alamo Square is cozy and easy and the prices are great.  The salmon tartare is delicious! Yummy place for a date or out with good friends.
author: Carolyn R.

description:
First thing I love about this place is their low prices!!! We got Escargo Farcies (baked escargo with garlic, butter and garlic butter) and smoked salmon. They both were good, but wasn't impressive. We were almost full after these 2 appetizers by the time our entrees arrived. But the big entrees were soo delicious that we finished them all. We got day's special Mahi Mahi and Trout with bearnaise sauce and both were amazing!

The place is small, so a group bigger than 6 people might have some difficult time in finding place during rush hours
author: Trinity N.

description:
Oh, I like it.  Excellent value.  The menu is quite straightforward French-leaning American food -- not much here that would surprise or shock the diner.  The décor is not what you would call edgy or original and the atmosphere can sometimes be a bit subdued.

But come in from the street, hungry and wind-blown, and you're in for a pleasant time.  There are several fish options and you choose the preparation and the sauce.  There's a steak, a fowl, a veg dish... all the basics.  You get what you ask for, and sometimes that's such a relief!  The wine list could use more Californian wines, in my opinion, but there are some tasty French wines on there.  The service has been great every time.  Lovely dip for the bread.

The bottom line: Good place to bring unadventurous eaters for a solid meal in a pleasant ambiance.  And for a reasonable price too!
author: Karen L.

description:
(Almost a four star)

"It's like fresh powder on the mountain," said Andre about the prix fixe entree we got (red snapper, pan seared, with some sort of yummy creamy sauce). The prix fixe is only $12.50 btw. A real steal.

We both thought the cauliflower soup had rather a lot of pepper but liked it and the banana bread pudding dessert quite a bit. 

I have almost given this a four star rating. The ambience is great. They need to refill water glasses more often, but I didn't find any snootiness in the staff. They weren't gregarious but it's also sometimes nice to be left alone. As long as they refill your water glass enough.
author: Tyler S.

description:
As the website says it is quite the good example of a good neighborhood restaurant.

Inside the smallish front room there are plenty of mirrors and wood to give a cozy but roomy feel.  You will be close to your neighbors but everyone is friendly enough since the overall relaxed atmosphere.

The food is spot on.  I really like the idea of the fish choices, the manner cooked, and accompanying sauces.  Kind of like a build your own fish bar while not having to clean or cook it.  The specials are quite inviting as well and all the sides are solid as well.

The wine list is limited but has enough choices to satisfy you.

The desserts are fantastic and quite a good follow up.

The service was about average or above average.  Thoroughly friendly though.

I will be back for sure.  I recommend a reservation.
author: Chris D.

description:
The coolest thing about this place is that you get to choose exactly how you want your fish. Pick the fish, the preparation, and the sauce, and you get exactly what you want. Unfortunately, the food isn't fabulous - it was good, but not the best fish that I've had. However, its only $13.50 for an entree, which is at least $5 cheaper than most other seafood places.

And there is no corkage fee on Wednesday, so bring a bottle of wine.

Overall, a solid place to eat, but it didn't live up to the glowing reviews given by my roommate. I might go back, but there are so many other good restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Dana L.

description:
The fish is great, but I would avoid anything else.

If you don't like tons of salt and pepper on your dishes, ask them to lightly season your fish.

Terrible service, cramped tables (we had to push the table over to squeeze to the bench)
author: Ben S.

description:
We went for a friend's birthday and there were some good and bad about it.

BAD:
*We orginally hoped to get the Prix Fixe only to find that you could only order for parties of 4 or less. We were a party of 5.
*We were seated for quite some time and parties that were seated after us were served the complimentary bread BEFORE us.
*There was something in the bottom of 2 out of the 5 water glasses.
*Dark atmosphere, meant more for couples not groups.
*Ordered the catfish and it was just okay. Seemed to be undercooked.
*The pom frites that accompanied the mussels were too salty. I had to wipe off a good portion with my napkin.

GOOD:
*the crab risotto GRUB. If it was just a bigger portion I would soooooooo order that as my entree. That's where my 2 stars fall.
*the snapper that my friend ordered, which was the special, was definitely delish as well.
author: Dina V.

description:
Meh. We went there for the $50 New Year's Eve prix fixe. The steak tartare was overly salty and the crab risotto was drowned in a sweet syrup and had the constituency of cheap tuna salad instead of risotto (the menu said "crab risotto" but I wouldn't have called it that). The main course (roasted halibut) was lukewarm and dry, and the side vegetables, although a creative mix, were poorly executed, i.e. limp with little taste.

Very disappointing.
author: John C.

description:
Great seafood restaurant, excellent value. I came here with my mom before the opera and we really enjoyed our meal. The bread came with a delectable pesto dipping sauce that we completely devoured. We shared the mussels and escargot appetizers. The mussels were especially delicious and we enjoyed dipping bread in the tasty white wine broth. The escargot was prepared with butter, parmesan cheese and garlic sauce. Very rich and yummy. 

We then split a sea bass entree which was seared with a sweet and sour chili sauce, jasmine rice, long green beans and shitake mushrooms. The sea bass was perfectly cooked. My only complaint is that the mushrooms were very salty. Otherwise the flavors of the dish were wonderful. 

Despite what some other Yelpers have said, we actually had very good service. I'll definitely eat here again.
author: Jenny K.

description: Very good meal here, and the atmosphere is warm and romantic.  Very good service, interesting menu. We had no trouble getting a table on a weeknight, though reservations are needed for Fri and Saturday.
author: leah w.

description:
This place is such a cute, quaint little place. The fish is great, the wine is yummy, and that pear salad they have is scrumptious! 
This is a great place for a quiet, romantic, private dinner. 
Also, there pre fix menu is the way to go!
author: Shawn P.

description:
Not really sure what I can add to what others have said about this place, but we found this to be an excellent choice for an inexpensive, yet intimate dinner on a couples' night out.

Since everyone gets the prix fixe menu with a daily entree chosen by the chef, there's really not much sharing that goes on -- but the entree that I had (a panfried herbed snapper over risotto with veggies) was tasty. I agree with whomever asserted that the entree here was a tad on the salty side - I found myself getting thirsty after dinner.

I probably would have gotten the soup instead of the mediocre mixed greens salad... the cream of celery-but-a-fancier-word-for-celery sounded delicious, but salad just seemed sensible, you know? Dessert was a lemon tart that had a very edible crust.

Service here was also very prompt, friendly, and attentive... we were surprised that the restaurant wasn't more crowded. Parking in the neighborhood wasn't hard to find either. And all in all, you can't beat a $14.50 meal!
author: Marisa L.

description:
A darling place in a strange location. Nevertheless perfect for a date or to take out your parents perhaps or a good friend. Classy but not too fancy.

The fixed menu is reasonable indeed!

The menu is unique because you choose the fish and how it is going to be prepared.  So there are many combinations.

It gets a little pricey here if you wander from the fixed course meal, so be careful.  But DO support and check out this wonderful find!
author: Aaron W.

description:
I say this so many times and nobody listens, but I'll try again: The key to this place is to go at off-times. It's a tiny little place. Show up at 8:00 on Saturday and you'll write a review about it being too crowded. Show up only during the prix fixe and you'll complain that the manager was too rushed. Well, of course! He's trying to get all the cheapskates' meals out at once.

I, taking my wonderful advice, showed up at 7, right after the prix fixe, before the rush. Got wonderful service, free parking, great atomosphere, tasty wine from a nice wine list, and delicious seafood with yummy sides. It felt exactly like a French bistro, including the kind of service that Americans call "slightly slow" but the French call "letting you alone to enjoy your food and your companions' company."

I'll be back, but I probably won't see you, because you'll probably go during the rush times, because nobody ever listens to me.
author: Tim B.

description:
I glanced at some of the other reviews before giving my review because I was curious how anyone would not love the food at Alamo Square Seafood Grill and why this place is only a 3 1/2 stars. 

My answer:  Service.  In regards to people complaining about the service, I can understand what you mean, there was only one person working there and it did take a little while; however, if you're not in a rush and don't mind a little wait while you enjoy your company; Alamo Square Seafood Grill is a great place to have a nice leisurely dinner and enjoy good food and our server was friendly.  Though going with a group of six worked fine for us, it was on a weeknight.  It's a small place, so probably not good for a big group on the weekend.

The food at Alamo Square Seafood Grill is amazing and is somewhat hidden in the Alamo Square area.  I had the grilled New York steak and the soup of the day, French onion soup.  I thought both were delicious.  The seasoning on the pieces of steak was top notch and the French onion soup was unlike any French onion soup I've had previously; it wasn't overload with cheese or onions; it was just really good, tasty, and uniquely flavored.  The majority of our group of six ordered fish and all enjoyed their dishes.
author: Josh K.

description:
Our main complaint about Alamo Square Seafood Grill is that parking was tough.  We had to circle for 10+ minutes before we found something on the street, and there really isn't any paid parking nearby, so that wasn't an option.

The food was awesome, though, and VERY reasonably priced.  I tried the shellfish bouillabaisse, which was really yummy and has two different kinds of fresh fish in it (salmon and white fish of some sort), lots of tail-on shrimp, mussels, oysters, and calamari.  It was huge.

Others in my group tried the red snapper, the mahi mahi special, the hangar steak, and the vegetable risotto.  The fish was very fresh and well-prepared.

Dessert was a little more disappointing -- the tiramisu needed more rum and it was a little too "cakey," as the bf rightly said.

Service was pretty good.  I'm a fan.  A pretty unpretentious local place, and they switch up the types of fish they have, depending on what they can get fresh.  Their claim to fame is that you can order the fish prepared in a variety of ways (peppercorn, beurre blanc, etc.).
author: Christina Y.

description:
Earlier this summer, I was bitching to friends about how seafood on the west coast just could not hold a candle to even the cheapest dive-iest joint in New England.  To prove there's at least good seafood in San Francisco, I was brought by some friends to the Alamo.

Although you won't hear me say the seafood here is as good as New England, I can say this is very good seafood.  There are definately other items on the menu but the seafood is where its at.

There are a list of sauces you can pick from, then the owner or server will tell you what's fresh for seafood that day.  This is good stuff.  I've been twice now and had the Green Pepper sauce and tried the blackened, which isn't really a sauce but is still delicious.

As pointed out in other reviews, Wednesday is a great day to go because they have free corkage night.  You can take up to 2 bottles of wine and they will pop it and serve it for you with no charge.

Love the atmosphere, staff, cleanliness, open kitchen and really good food.  Would be 5 stars if the fish weren't served with a plain old side of rice and vegetables.  I see myself becoming a regular here.

FYI... They do serve wine and beer so don't take free corkage night for their not having a license.
author: William R.

description: I haven't been to the Alamo Square Seafood Grill in years. I moved back from NYC two years ago and remembered it as a cosy little place with reasonable seafood. I was right about the "cozy" but wrong about the "reasonable" . The salmon that I ordered (blackened) was fantastic. Wonderful service and great desserts. My compliments to everyone involved. Why did I wait so long to return?
author: Robert S.

description:
Been to Alamo Square a number of times and have never been disappointed.  The restaurant is cozy and warm feeling - though the seating isn't the most comfortable for tall people...as the table legs are a bit awkward and you can find yourself often kicking the person next to you or the table leg.  

Additionally parking in this neighborhood is not only scarce, but one wrong turn can take you from the nice part of Hayes Valley to the not-so-nice part of Hayes Valley where you might be a little wary of leaving your car parked.  However, this can all be overlooked because of the food!  

Alamo Square has some of the best food for the price.  A MUST TRY is the risotto - if you ever see the rabbit risotto on special - order two.  The boyfriend and I found ourselves fork-fighting over the last spoonful.  

Additionally, every night except Wednesday they offer a fantastic prix fixe deal.  For $12.50 you get an appetizer, choice of entry, and dessert - a big plus for anyone watching their wallet.  Wednesday night is an all-together different perk...no corkage fee.  

The waiter, while often the only waiter, can seem a little distant at first (he's just busy) but is quick to offer recommendations from the menu and wine pairings.  

All-in-all great meal, ambiance, and value.  I'll definitely be going back!
author: Alison L.

description:
A wonderfully quaint hidden jem on Fillmore street. The server (is he also the owner?) was a little out there, but he was accomidating and quick. 
I ordered the pate plate for an appetizer, and it was pretty good. The pate was a little congealed (sp?) in consistancy, but it was housemade and had a great flavor. 
I had the mussles with french fries for dinner (I know its an appetizer, but I just loooove mussles with fries!!), and they were outstanding. Although, a couple of them were unopened (meaning they were dead and un-edible), and a couple of the shells were cracked. 
My friend got the crab cake (AMAZING) and the roasted summer vegetable gnocci (SOOOOO GOOOD!!!). We split a bottle of the cheapest champagne ($25 for a bottle), and the bill came to $60 including tax!!! 
Delicious upscale food on a moderate budget...JUST WHAT I LIKE!!
I will most definitley be back!
author: Keila E.

description:
My husband took me here for our first date...okay, it wasn't really a date, just the first time we'd seen each other in 5 years and more like a chance to catch up with each other and think it was another 6 weeks before we had a real date.

But, onto the review - the food is excellent and very reasonably priced. The service can be hit and miss (date with now hubby had excellent service...other nights it's been slower). Some nights they let you bring your own wine and don't charge corkage...but, you'll have to call ahead cause I can't remember which night that is. 

In a city of great restaurants, it's rare that I go back to the same one more than once or twice - especially if it's not in my neighborhood and I have to drive to get there...but, Alamo Square Grill is one of those places that I'll make the effort to go to once or twice a year.
author: Amanda S.

description: After my last review, the owner reached out to me on yelp and told me he would like to invite me in to try the restaurant again and that it would be his "treat." We arranged last night for my boyfriend and I to come in. Andre wasn't there and none of the staff had been informed that we were coming in. It was awkward trying to explain to them that Andre had contacted us and offered to pick up our meal. I just let it drop and tried to enjoy the meal. The food was slightly better then last time, not great (uninspired is the word that comes to mind). The server was nice but I was very disappointing that the owner had completely forgotten or blown off his invitation. I wouldn't have gone back to the restaurant if Andre hadn't reached out to me and I ended up paying for the full meal. The whole evening was just kind of awkward.
author: Curtner J.

description:
Great food, poor service.  Laughable service.  But if you're not in a hurry, it's a good place to go though. 

 Four of us went there last night and literally waited thirty minutes before our order was taken.  The place was not even half full so I'm not sure what the wait was about.  Plus, there is a fixed price special that for some reason is only offered to tables of 1 or 2.  Being a table of four, we did not qualify.  Again, not sure what that was about....And lastly, the waiter arbitrarily removed water glasses from the table of only some of our party.  So I guess some of us don't get water for the 2nd half of the meal?  Strange...strange...

However, when we did finally get our meal (about an hour later), it was very well done.  The seafood was amazing and the dessert was incredible.   Despite the mind bogglingly bad service, the food was good enough that I would go back.
author: Juliana X.

description:
The food is better than decent.  My boyfriend and I live nearby and we made reservations for dinner on Valentine's Night -- it didn't matter -- we still had to wait almost almost an hour to sit down (although the glass of wine we were offered helped a *tiny* bit).
