Like I said, the meal was decent and good.  We left the place satisfied.  Then, I got my credit card statement... the restaurant charged my account twice.... that sucked!  I had to call the bank and deal with that headache.  Nice place with good intentions.  Not top notch service.

UPDATE: We finally went back after that poor V-Day experience.  It was MUCH better.  Don't go for V-Day.  Go for Ordinary Day dinners for something several steps up from ordinary..
author: Karen C.

description:
Two stars for being charming. It's a very cute restuarant with good energy, and not at all loud or hectic.

Minus 1 star for not being more hectic. The restaurant was packed on a Friday night, and they had only two people working the floor. These same two poor souls had to greet, seat, serve and bus. Unreal. But that's cool, I can chill out with a bottle of wine - except it took 20 minutes just to take that wine order. Once we ordered dinner, our meal took between 45-55 minutes to arrive. But that's cool, I'm enjoying my company, the wine, the atmosphere, I don't have anywhere to be.

Minus 2 stars for a New York Steak ordered medium rare, served medium to medium well and unbearably salty. My lips are still stinging!

I am only one heaping tablespoon of salt away from giving this place 4 stars and becoming a regular. Alas I can't see fit to return, fool me once....
author: Griffin L.

description:
What a shame. I was excited to try this bistro b/c of all the good reviews, but I was disappointed. We had the pate appetizer (approx. $6), 2 Kir Royales ($6 each), and we each picked a fish entree. I wasn't a big fan of having to figure out which fish, which cooking style and which sauce (isn't that why I go to a restaurant with professional chefs?).

I ended up choosing grilled ahi tuna with red wine reduction and green peppercorn. Darn. Awfulcombo. See, I'm not the chef here. The fish happened to be drowned butter (ahi tuna in butter?). My mister had snapper with red wine reduction and veal glas, which was better than mine, but my little sister could've made it at home. The dessert, strawberry shortcake, looked good but didn't come through. The table next to me didn't like it either and described it well: "It's like a muffin with some strawberries and confectioner sugar sprinkled around it." 

Finally, the service was not only slow as molasses, but incompetent. We ordered wine and it never came. There was one waiter for the whole place! On a Saturday night! C'mon now.... We were there for an hour and half, and not because they wanted to give us a taste of France. 

Instead of this place, go to Chapeau! for their early bird special. You'll be floored.
author: Sumi Y.

description:
Cheap eats.  Sure, the service and wine list could be better, but it's such a good value.  If you are looking for a low-key,  typical evening out, this place is ideal.  For two: appetizers, dinner (blackened ahi and new york strip), bottle of wine ($20 p.noir)  and a shared dessert, we had a bill (before tip) of $59.

Seafood is great here; who can complain that SF is not affordable?
author: E L.

description:
My salmon was good the service was not. 
Slooooooow as molasses.  
Great prices though, but extremely slow service.  Great date place, if you were looking for a non-rushed dinner/date.  Calamari was good. The beurre blanc sauce was tasty too.  
Wish there were halves here they would have gotten 3.5 from me.
author: Pug P.

description:
WoW! Just had my first meal at Alamo Square Seafood Grill and it was fantastic! Not a single complaint. The waiter, Todd, who took our reservation, was really great and flexible as I called and changed my reservation twice! When we got to the restaurant, he shook my hand and already had our table set up with waters poured. The ambiance is pretty great, as it is a nice intimate restaurant. Perfect for a casual date, or a meal with friends. 

We started with an appetizer of calamari and the trout salad...both delicious! Even the bread came with a wonderful dipping sauce.  For entrees the four of us decided to go with their fish specialty, in which you select the fish, the way you want it cooked, and the sauce you want with it. Rather than deciding, we asked Todd for a recommendation and he selected all four combos for us. We each tried some of the 4 dishes and like everything else...delicious! All of this including 2 glasses of wine, total $95.00, (not including tip)...very reasonable.  I can't wait to go back!!
author: Dan S.

description:
This place was hyped by a good buddy of mine and I think I set my expectations to high.  My overall experience covers the gamut.
The place was CHEAP and if you are looking to go out and enjoy a nice atmosphere on a small budget... Alamo is a great bet.  

The wine list is dirt cheap as are the dish prices.   
My biggest issue was that everything was over cooked and over salted.  The "choose your own adventure" preperation for the seafood selections was TGI Fridays in every way.  BOO!
Service was very good as was the atmosphere.  

All and all, if you are broke and trying to impress a date that has low standards of food quality... this place is Perfecto.
author: Garren K.

description:
I've had some pretty decent meals here in the past...but the last time I wasn't having it. Maybe it was the cockroach crawling on the wall right behind my head. Maybe it was my uninspired meal which was a little too greasy for my taste and their not so stellar wine list (you know it's bad when the server describes one bottle as awful).  Nonetheless, service was nice and they tried to be helpful. 

I haven't been back since that meal...and I don't even miss it.
author: Dee Dee N.

description:
Unfortunately this restaurant did not win me over.  My dad loves to go out for seafood whenever he visits San Francisco.  I had heard good things about Alamo Square Seafood Grill so we decided to give it a try.  My overall impression was that it felt pretty obvious they were cutting corners to save/make money and it really detracted from the overall experience.

The decor and ambiance are cute and welcoming, however there is not much space and you may have no choice but to sit near the drafty entrance.  I liked the color scheme. There is a cute indoor window to the upper loft that has potential to be a cute feature, but instead there was some mess from the office above just showing through into the restaurant below.  And the tables and chairs are on the small side, giving it that cramped feeling that is quite common in San Francisco restaurants.

I went with the pre-fixe menu. I guess I don't know what I was expecting ordering 3 courses for $12, but it just didn't impress.  The main problem was that I didn't get what I ordered.  I was told the salad was plain mixed greens, however it had carrots, tomatoes, and shaved fennel in it.  That would have been fine, but it was odd that the waitress didn't explain that when asked.  Also there was a black spot on one of my carrot slices, kind of off-putting.

I thought the mahi-mahi was supposed to come with some type of mixed-pepper  topping, but instead it came in a an undiscernable reddish brown sauce (red bean?) that was tasty, but unappealing looking, and it was quite cold!  The rice was very basic and fine.  The vegetable selection was mixed squash, which I don't typically care for.  It was pretty tasty as the veggies were doused in some type of oil or butter, but overall it was just an uninspired dish that I could have made easily at home.

The biggest disappointment was when dessert was served.  I saw the tables next to us received their bread pudding, however we were delivered a white mound covered in almond slices and what looked like Hershey's chocolate syrup.  I realized this was the wrong dessert, and wanted to tell our waitress but she did not visit our table for another 5-10 minutes, even as we tried to get her attention.  We decided to bite into the dessert we had been served, because we figured it would probably be a decent slice of pie or something. It must have been  their take on meringue, which was essentially just lightly whipped egg whites in some milky sauce - it was pretty bad and very cheap (along the same line as the bread pudding would have been I suppose).

We ordered two different glasses of red wine (a pinot and a syrah) and both tasted a little off (cheap, slightly sour).

My dad had the fried calamari appetizer (which had little popcorn shrimp mixed into the basket somehow) and blackened salmon which I thought was pretty good, but the portion was definitely on the small side.  My dad didn't even finish it.  He is not a picky eater at all, and for him it is usually seen as a rare treat to go out to eat, but at the end of the meal he asked me how many restaurants are in San Francisco.  I guessed it to be about 3000, and he just said "well, ok, I guess we'll never have to come to this one again."

That's what ultimately prompted to write this review.  Perhaps our waitress and the cook were just having a bad night, but I was very disappointed with our choice of restaurant, and I don't think I'll be visiting the Alamo Seafood Grill again!
author: Amy S.

description:
I have been here several times before and have never been disappointed.  Great neighborhood place! It was not busy at all this visit.

I like their snapper and the blanc butter sauce.  Simple rice and vegetables to accompany the fish.

Had a mocha - wish it was in a porcelain cup instead of glass....it was too hot to pickup.  But it was nice-sized glass mug!  Kudos for that.

Great prices - great place for an intimate date.  Bring your own wine though...
author: Jackie M.

description:
I've been a patron of this place since 2002.  I recall running into Matt Gonzalez there when he was running for mayor; and later reading it was his favorite place to eat in his district.

I have seen many changes in personnel, some for the better and others not so much.  I have been there on nights when the service was poor, or just slow, but I have always been willing to forgive it.  The place has always had this offbeat, French, sit down and enjoy slow food feel about it.

The fish is always spot on.  So are the crabcakes.  Order a crabcake appetizer and your favorite fish grilled with beurre blanc.  Other reviewers point out that Wednesdays are free corkage nights.  Pack up a couple of those Napa wines you have been saving from your last trip north and enjoy with the best fish around.  Last Wednesday we brought two nice bottles with us.  Appetizers, entrees and dessert for three people came in under a hundred bucks including tip.

I have been to better quality restaurants but I have never been to a place that does such a good job so consistently as Alamo Square Grill.
author: Cheezy P.

description: Its inexpensive, but I don't want inexpensive non-tasty food.  If you must eat here, get the chicken.  Ya, the chicken at a seafood restaurant.
author: Wakako U.

description:
This place is half a block from my apartment, and I've always wanted to go, but I've never been able to convince my boyfriend to due to their mediocre Yelp reviews :).

So when a friend came to visit and mentioned it looked cute, I thought I'd take the chance to go.  I have to say all the reviews are pretty spot on. The place is cute and the food is affordable, but the food is not stellar.. nor is the service.

I would definitely eat a snack before going here, as they don't take your order for some time.  They did bring us extra bread, as my friend and I killed the first round in the half hour we waited for our food, so that was nice.  The steak was good when it finally arrived, but something was up with the spinach and neither of us could eat it (some sort of sour taste).  The fries were tasty, but my friend mentioned they looked and tasted exactly like McDonalds... which are cheaper and just down the street!  Finally we tried for a while, unsuccessfully,  to get the bill.  The place is small, and was not full, so I sort of just started feeling like i was not cool enough to get the waiters attention.  At one point he walked by us to greet some people walking in and I reached up to tap his arm to get his attention.  He turned around so fast into my hand though, that i ended up fully grabbing his arm in a creepy/ pushy sort of way, which caused him to look down and give me a look that made me feel pretty rude.. but i really just wanted to give him a tap!

Anyway, I think i got carried away with this one... I'd probably go again at some point, because it is so close, but hopefully not anytime soon.
author: Erin D.

description: When I ordered my Ahi tuna steak I wished that it would be perfectly seared on the outside and tartar on the inside and voila! It arrived just as I wanted it- it was perfect. The ambiance is quaint and elegant and the food is very impressive for the price. Highly recommended.
author: Kate M.

description: Great restaurant - the food was excellent. You have to try the shrimp ceviche appetizer - it was phenomenal (I would have that as my entire meal!) My girlfriend and I went for the first time after snagging a reservation on Open Table. The niche decor was lovely and the whole atmosphere made for a terrific meal. I had the crab cakes as my entree but I'm definitely returning so I can try their fish specialities. All terrific and tasty, thanks for having us!
author: Erica L.

description:
They have different menus!

The food is still yummy... The service is still pretty slow.
A good neighborhood joint, nonetheless.
author: Tulip F.

description: We walked in and the ambiance was great.  Small, quaint and very quiet.  We didnt have a reservation, but we seated promptly at 6:00 on a Wednesday.  They have free corkage on Wednesday night.  We brought our 3 and five year old and they really enjoyed their steak.  Not great for kids, but the servers adapted really well and were very accommodating.  The potato leek soup was superb.  All the fish was cooked perfectly.  The sauces we great as well.  The free bread and pesto dipping oil was a huge hit as well.  You cant go wrong here!!
author: Ryan M.

description: I'm not sure what happened in the last year with this place, but whatever changed has turned me off completely. I absolutely agree with everyone else now- rude service, and not to mention SLOW. There is a balance between being busy and maintaining a level of customer care, and Alamo Square is far from meeting that expectation. I planned a group dinner here for my girlfriend's birthday, and we were late to her party because of the unhurried and callous pace of the waitstaff. The food is still good, but in a city like ours where great restaurants are a dime a dozen, it really is about the service. Aurevoir.
author: Alice P.

description:
Rub the beurre blanc all over my body. Service was friendly and helpful. The very fresh trout with aforementioned sauce was superb. Free corkage on Wednesday night makes it all the more worthwhile. Desserts are average but filled with sugar and sugar is never a bad thing. 

Likelihood of me going back: 95%
What are the three magic words? Something Smells Fishy
author: MegaDollars I.

description:
Had a fabulous dinner here with my husband and our family last night.  We arrived before the rush (7pm) and brought a bottle of wine (free corkage Wed.).  I mention the arrival time because I think arriving before the restaurant was packed resulted in our receiving the good service many other Yelpers mention was lacking during their visits.  The restaurant only employs one waiter, it seems.  He was a great server, but once the restaurant got packed (right about the time we were finishing our mains) the poor guy was running around like a madman trying to take care of 20 tables!  

The food itself was FANTASTIC.  We started with escargot (very tender, not overly garlicy) and calamari (very good, but nothing special--ended up being more excited by the white bean and field green salad the calamari was served upon).  4 of the 5 members of our party got the prix fixe menu which that night included a starter of lobster bisque (creamy, yummy), melt-in-your-mouth blackened salmon with rice, veggies and a tomato-caper relish, and a chocolate souffle (sadly, the one less-than-stellar item: part of the problem was in calling the dessert a souffle.  Souffle by definition is light and fluffy.  This chocolate cake-like item was dense as a rock and nearly as hard.  The flavor was fine without being note-worthy.  Worth getting as part of the prix fixe, otherwise, not so much).  The fifth member of our party got the filet minion with a green peppercorn sauce and potatoes with pancetta.  The steak was a flavor-sensation (wonderful char on the meat also gave the tender cut a great textural contrast) and the pancetta served with the potatoes was smoky and a wonderful counterpoint to the potatoes.
author: H B.

description:
One of the RUDEST services EVER!

Came here with family after reading amazing reviews, yet was quickly disappointed.  

Not only did it take forever to find a parking spot in that area, which I am used to, but once I got inside to meet up with family no one came to check on us right away to take drink orders or let us know what the specials were.  Finally a waitress came by took our drink order & appetizer order, briefly described the fishes of the day & walked away.

Then this very RUDE waiter comes by, I am guessing he was the owner since he was doing every job in there except being kind to customers, asks what we would like to drink & I let him know that the other waitress took our order - he immediately snaps back well what were they - well let's see if you were a waiter wouldn't you just go ask your co-worker what the table ordered & fill the order??

The I ask him what the specials were for the day pointing to the scribbled chalkboard - he replies "What would you like to know about them"  I laugh thinking you got to be kidding me that you are actually this vain & rude!  Oh and the night just goes on from there... meal was eh okay - lumpy mashed potatoes, over-done mahi mahi, burned creme brulee & pretty much the worst service ever - not once did he come to check in to see how we are or if we needed anything else...

Would not recommend this place & would not go back.
author: K. R.

description:
The Alamo Grill from the looks of it one of those places that you would expect to have really good food--the kind of place that's a little neighborhood "secret" or something--with lots of "regulars".  Well, I'm not sure about the regulars part, but it definitely does not deliver on the food front.  So much for the cute, alluring outside.

While there wasn't anything glaringly wrong, nothing was brilliantly great, either.  In fact, it's a little tough to write a review on a place when I have almost no recollection of the meal (and not a result of too much wine, thank you) except that the cooks kept yelling things out to the wait staff on the floor--reminiscent at times of the "whhooooppp" that brought down  Howard Dean's campaign a while back.

Aside from that, the best way to describe this place is "beige":  nothing remarkable one way or another, run-of-the-mill food and mediocre service.  My guess is that it does okay because of its location and lack of nearby competition beyond a liquor store on the corner (yes, this does beat out a Slim Jim and diet Coke for dinner).  If you absolutely can't get out the neighborhood to find something better, then it's a good bet, but I wouldn't dillydally with heading to Alamo Grill otherwise.
author: Annie B.

description:
It's delicious boutique restaurants like Alamo Square that make San Francisco the mecca for foodies that it is. 

Tucked away in the middle of a residential block, Alamo Square Seafood Grill is so tiny and unassuming from the outside that I lived 2 blocks away from it for three months without even knowing it was there. When I finally did wander in for dinner, I was blown away by the gourmet food, friendly wait staff and affordable prices. 

They have a different seasonal seafood special every night, and their soup du jour is always delicious. They also have a menu in which you can pick from 4-5 types of fresh fish, then choose the way you want it cooked and finally decide on one of the many delicious sauces to accompany it. 

If you live in the neighborhood and still have never been Alamo Square Seafood Grill, do yourself a favor and go tonight. You will not be disappointed. 

Wednesday is BYOW night and they don't charge a corkage fee. If you are going on a weekend be sure to make reservations; not only is it very popular in the neighborhood, but it is tiny and only seats about 40 people.
author: Casey C.

description:
Huge fan, can great date place.  
Food is great for the price (especially if chef lance is working).  I have never had bad food - in probably 20 visits - but would recommend you go for the special it is almost always the best thing of the night.
Great small atmosphere to chill and have a conversation, be patient, and relax.
author: Sam R.

description:
bummer of a place. 
I moved into the neighborhood a few months ago - I was really excited for a neighborhood place! The first time I went, I almost had to hold my friend back from making a deal about how incredibly rude and obnoxious the server was - the bald headed guy. We left sort of awe-struck at how he could be such a jerk. It was not a busy night, we weren't making things difficult - but I got the clear feeling he would have preferred us not be there at all. The food is uninspired -  - ya know its got all the ingredients and it is edible but not thoughtful.

It's been a few months. When I walk by at night I check to see if the bald guy is there - trying to figure out if he is the owner or a server that is about to be fired. Seems like he's there a lot.

So, last night I decide to give it another try - mostly cause i don't want to wonder far from home. Never again. same server, same rude service, and same mediocre food. 

Please fire that guy or buy him out and make this the wonderful neighborhood place it could be. 

also they were playing counting crows while we were eating - what?
author: slow c.

description: Was a great place to have dinner.  In the last year, this place has gone downhill.  Service has become rude.  Entrees have shrunk while the price is the same, about $17 per plate.  Sad to see a nice place go out like that.
author: trent w.

description: One of my favorite places in the neighborhood.  Great fish that they can prepare in a number of ways, escargots, soups, etc.  Eaten here many different times and always thought it was worth it.  Kinda tough to get a seat sometimes, but that's common in SF.
author: Pedro B.

description: this place is just one reason why you need to check out all the local spots in SF.  it's a hidden gem that few would ever think to check out unless you live walking distance.  which thankfully, i used to do.  i was so sufficiently impressed that i trot back there every year or so to see if it's still holding up.  the modestly priced but stand-out wines, the fish, the steak, the profiteroles.  the chardonney, the fries, the poached pear salad.  the unassuming wait staff.  it's not a place that is going to hit the crazy high marks on food critics to make it the "Toast of SF" or the latest Flavor of the month Hot New Spot, but what a stand-out place for being in a hidden location and having a very, very low profile!  check it out.
author: dan h.

description:
I realize many people have already said this, but I feel it warrants repeating since they still haven't made any changes - the service here is SLOW and not terribly friendly.

At one point the guy said to me "are you ready to order?" and when I said yes, he then walked away and didn't come back for a long time.  I am not sure what about "yes" was unclear.

I must say that the food was in fact quite tasty and very reasonably priced but I don't know if that is enough to bring me back.
author: A. D.

description: Alamo Square Seafood Grill is a warm, inviting space with a small selection of fish (and other dishes) at a very reasonable price. I especially liked the prix fixe dinner, including dessert!
author: wendy B.

description: Totally a fan and looking forward to going back! Just didn't give a 5 because I definitely could have used a bit of extra time between my starter and main because the starter was HUGE! Everything was delicious, and they had a deal going that all wine was 1/2 price for the bottle. Amazing food, good wine and service was fine too. Lovely atmosphere, very good for intimate dinner with your partner or a small group. Definitely recommended!
author: Cl B.

description: I hadn't had fish for a long time so I jumped on opentable to get some points and this place came up; I always wanted to try it and I got some points and a great fresh trout! You get to pick how you want it cooked (I picked sauted) and then you pick a sauce (I picked the beure blanc - Wow! Perfect!). It also came with some veggies - horrible! Take them off the sides, please, and a decent wine list and a great price for fresh fish. So 4 stars for the fish -1 for the veggies... The profiteroles were quite good, too. Atmosphere is cozy and low-key, good date spot or after a tiring day at work. Service was not bad but rather slow.
author: Chris D.

description: I took my parents to dinner here not too long ago and they both loved the food.  My mom and I ordered the prix fixe menu which was the perfect amount of food.  Great affordable neighborhood restaurant.
author: Nat O.

description:
We came here 2 weeks ago. I miss SF food since I moved out of SF 6 months ago. This is a very small restaurant that has only about 10 small tables, if that. I don't think people go out of their way to come here, as it's pretty difficult to park. 1/2 of the restaurant filled up during our stay here. 

The menu is very scant; there are only a few items to choose from. They specialize in fish. My hubs had a salmon and I had a mahi mahi. The fish dishes were ok. But it would be nice to have a bigger selectioin to choose from.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I really like this place.  Wish I went more often.

Excellent food.  I have always been served by Todd who is among the best waiters in the city.
author: The P.

description: This is my "go to" restaurant in SF. I get to Alamo Seafood Grill every time I'm in the SF area usually 4 to 5 times a year. Just cant say enough good things about the food at this restaurant. Yes, sometimes the service is slow, and it seems there never is enough staff on hand, but somehow I think this is intentional.This intention gives time to talk, enjoy your company and take in the cozy atmosphere. I've had most of the items on the menu on multiple trips, and found it always consistent yet adventurous in its composition.Do yourself a favor, and visit this restaurant.
author: Mike A.

description: Just wanted to say that the owner and waitress that night did take the time to contact two members of my party about our horrible experience there.  Everything I stated below still stands, but I appreciate them reaching out to us, so I'm adding one star back.
author: LaSha G.

description: Wonderful food-I had forgotten that they do a prix fixe that is SUCH a great deal. Don't forgot their dessert. The chocolate cake was amazing!
author: Michelle W.

description: One of the greatest places to go on a date in the city. Small, cozy, romantic, the waiters are actually french, great wine selection, and the best desserts around. I would eat here more if I weren't poor.
author: Veronica B.

description: Straight to the point service. Simple, small but suberb menu. Manages to be casual yet elegant and very intimate.
author: Drew I.

description:
Here's the story:

So, my boss took all the people in my office (all 4 of us) out to dinner for the Holidays (It's not as nice as it sounds, the company paid for it, but I digress) Anyway, I'm always a little hesitant about these excursions. I mean you see these people all day, do you really want to have dinner with them? Also, will you get drunk and make inappropriate advances on your female co-workers, even though you are gay? Will you just sit in awkward silence until someone says something stupid about the weather or the computer problems you've 
been having?
One of our number suggested Alamo Seafood Grill and off we went.
I have to say, the food was pretty good. So good in fact, we were able to talk about it almost all night! Almost no awkward silences or stupid comments about how cold it is!
We started with a few appetizers - calamari and something and something - I don't remember. All were good. The salads were a little too large to accompany a main course, but mine was tasty and full of Maytag Blue Cheese which I love. The main course, for me, consisted of an amazing flat iron steak over a great mushroom infused mashed potato. The dessert highlight was a fresh mint creme brulee.
All in all a great night and I made it through the whole thing without doing anything inappropriate - almost :)

(DISCLAIMER: I like all of my co-workers and any bitchiness in the above review is for sheer comic effect only! Similarity to any coworkers, living or dead, is purely coincidental.)
author: Jamie M.

description: I was so excited to try this place. and wow, what a let down.   My girlfriend and I get there and the place is pretty empty, so we're thinking "yay, great service!"  3 other tables are seated shortly after us.  The waiter takes all their orders before us.  We finally have our order taken.  My glass of wine takes 30 minutes to arrive.  In the mean time, the three other tables already have their appetizers/food.  We eventually get our appetizer (mussels) which are way overcooked and dried up. When our main dish finally arrives, I get the wrong food.  I tell the waiter.  He doesn't correct it.  I wait another 25 minutes or so.  I'm so hungry I eat it.  And on top of it...it wasn't that great (bland, overcooked).   I'll never go back.  Awful service. blah food.
author: Amanda G.

description: At first blush, way snooty... But order the Brazilian Wine and the waiter lights up.(He always recommends it.) Get there between 5:30-7:30 for the Prix Fixe (~$12) Great Deal! The food is great and the ambiance is nice. It helps that it's right around the corner from my house.  The creme brule is awesome... Perfect with a little bit of their excellent tiramisu.
author: Ben K.

description:
homey & cozy atmosphere + tasty solid food.

a good find for the Alamo Square area since there's not so many restaurants that cumulate the 2 features around the neighborhood.

- food : 2 of us went for the grilled fish which was tasty and well cooked. a good bargain for $12. 2 other went for the daily special which was absolutely stunning - grilled lamb in its juice served with a carrot & cauliflower risotto..... GOD THAT WAS GOOD!!
we finally shared 2 'profiteroles' for desert and honestly, they've been the best i've had in a very long time : pastry was freshly made tender, chocolate was dark and not too sweet. a de-lish! 

- service : we get there around 9pm, without reservation, on a packed wednesday night... we were given a table within 15mns. the service wasn't very quick, I agree with other yelpers but it was OK. at least, we had time to chat without beeing rushed!! 
well, the French way actually...
author: lucy b.

description: if you're looking for an accessible seafood restaurant with a French flair, this is the spot. the service is good, but they go through help regularly so not sure how any night will be other than the food is always great. You choose the type of fish you'd like and how you would like it prepared. lots of options, and good apps. They have mid-priced wines and a set of drinks on the menu to keep it easy to serve. There is no full bay, just specific items on the menu. Specials are always good, and they make a nice risotto as well. Enjoy.
author: Adam X.

description: I love this restaurant. You pick the fish, you pick the sauce, you pick the cooking method, and they do it up for you fantastically. Nothing too fancy, just really, really good fish. I'm less fond of the appetizers and desserts, but you don't really need them when the main course is so good. Charming atmosphere. Great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Julia B.

description:
Well no stars for you Alamo square grill....... even though I had to put one URGHHHH!
Too bad you have good food too, but boy your customers should not be treated like a piece of dirt.
So I called that day for an evening dinner for 8 pm- upon arriving on time. My husband and I nearly stood in the door for 20 min before we were even greeted by a single person, mind you they walked by us over a dozen times. We had to get the Manager/host/waiter, to let him know we arrived.  He said he will get us when our table is ready, not even sorry we don't have a table for you since you made a reservation for 8pm. Well we waited and waited and watched 3 other couples without reservations- be seated before us. It was then almost 9pm.
It is extremely hard to piss my husband off- but they did and we had to walk out.
We will never frequent your Establishment ever again.
Hey people if you don't want to be seated and you want a bad attitude from the manager who will wait on you- then this is your place.
These days it takes more than good food- you have to have service too.
I am just wondering why this manager still has a job?
What a shame such good food but such horrible service. 
Hey Alamo square Grill you really owe us an apology- we frequent your restaurant twice a month.  Oh yeah I forgot you don't care about your customers.
author: a g.

description: My boyfriend and I ate here on Valentine's Day and I have to say it is probably my favorite restaurant in SF. Quiet, intimate, friendly, no rushed atmosphere, and amazing food and wine. We ate there about 6 months ago and I can't even remember exactly what I ordered but I remember the whole experience being so relaxed and wonderful. This restaurant is truly a hidden gem in SF in a quieter neighborhood.
author: Mark S.

description: Went here for the first time and I really think this is a great neighborhood restaurant.  I thought the service was impeccable and very warm without being overly solicitous.  The food was yummy, plentiful, and quickly served.  We had the escargot which was prepared the way my French mother always makes it...YUMMY!  I had the seared ling cod with crab mashed potatoes and a beurre and Meyer lemon sauce with asparagus.  Needless to say, my plate was clean.  Dessert was the creme caramel and my friend had the tarte tatin.  Both of which were devoured.  I loved the atmosphere and the coziness to say nothing of the fact that I could hear myself and my friend's conversation without straining.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Jill D.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars to compensate for all you people giving it less than 3 who obviously don't know what the hell you're talking about :)  

I've been here twice now and, while the wait was different each time, the food and service were both great.  Now, if you expect servers to fawn all over you and treat you like a princess...you might not share my assessment of the service as it is more East Coast efficient than West Coast gregarious.  I was born in the Bay Area by the way so, don't mistake this for some nostalgic I-wish-everywhere-was-more-like-New-York kind of thing.

Still, there's simply no equivocating when it comes to the food.  It is consistently very good and an exceptional value in this expensive city.  Oh, and for a fish place they do a damn fine pork chop.
author: Joseph S.

description: So we decided to treat ourselves on a Friday night and came here. This is a cute little place not too far from my apartment, so it wins points for that. It lost a few points for the long wait despite having a reservation. (Service might not be this place's strongsuit). We were patient, though, and we quickly realized that the reason why it was packed that night is because the food is DELICIOUS! They cook up fresh seafood very very yummily. I had the special, the Chilean Sea Bass, and it was wonderful. My husband had the  Trout, which we both looved. Really, this places knows how to do seafood right. For the high quality and portion size, the prices are also more than reasonable. Despite the initial wait fiasco, we're definitely coming back here.
author: Kimi W.

description: Went here for dinner on Saturday night before a show at Yoshi's.  I was really impressed with our meal!  Delicious scallop salad, mahi mahi, and a great bottle of wine that didn't cost a paycheck.  The atmosphere was really nice, too - very cozy - and great service.  Definitely will be back if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Colleen M.

description: This place is amazing.  The food is always exceptional.  Their risotto is some of the best I've ever had.  Service can be a little bit on the slow side, but the ambiance is great.  I like to sit near the window on all the comfy pillows.  The best night to go is on Wednesday, when you can bring your own wine with no corkage fee.  Free wine means you can get out of there pretty easily for under $20 per person, even with an appetizer.  Other nights, they offer a $12.50 price fix menu with 3 courses.  Can't beat that anywhere.
author: matt c.

description:
After seeing this cute little restaurant several times and thinking it might be good, I finally decided to give it a try. What a mistake I made! First the host is a rude self absorbed man, who won't look at you until he's good and ready to. Had to wait 15 minutes although we had made reservations which is definitely the first loss of any points. The second loss comes from the two ladies who ran out screaming ahead of us. They were disgusted and we could only wonder why...until we got handed a glass of water with a cockroach floating in it. Not only did they give the same water to the ladies which is definitely disgusting...but then didn't notice it and gave it to us as well.  Should've been the first sign of a bad time, but I realize every place has roaches...it's just you don't want to see them and be reminded. 

So, after 10 minutes of no service and no attention, my girlfriend finally goes up to the counter with the glass and stands there for another 5 minutes without even a batted eyelash from the host. She finally just asks for sparkling water and gets dismissed by him. It finally took her telling him he needed to see something and gently pointed at the roach in the water before he even acknowleged she was there. 

His reaction "Oh you found it, we were looking for it" and the comped sparkling water are the only reason we might have stuck around. As we sat drinking our now sparkling water, the server came by to collect dishes from the neighboring tables. As she walked by me, she dropped a dirty fork from a dish down my back and heard it hit the floor. She doesn't notice it, and actually leaves it there the entire time. Then as she brings the mussels that we ordered, drops the fork for the mussels in my lap. 

Lots of strikes...but at this point we had a bottle of wine, and well...might as well see the visit to the end. 

The food: the mussels were seriously below average. Decent garlic butter sauce they were sitting in, but they were very fishy to the taste...something I've never experienced with mussels before. (an inclination of how well prepared they've been at other places). 

The saving grace for this place and the only reason they have 1 star is because the chilean sea bass and the grilled tuna were beyond delicious. Even though there was some severe stomach discomfort several hours later that prevented them from having 2 stars. Would I go back?  Hell no!!!
author: m p.

description: Bacon tastes good, even when places try to be high end and call it "pancetta". Due to the fact that bacon is oh so delicious and this place put it into risotto with shrimp and lemon, yum yum,  I would say try it. The service left a little something to be desired but they were attentive to our time commitments.
author: Roxane S.

description: I've been coming here for year's. I love seafood places that have a small cascade of cheesy plastic when you first walk through. Their wine list is pretty good and their selection of fish is divine. I love their soups and even better they have this flourless chocolate cake that will burn a place in your memory for days. It's soooo good - I highly recommend this place if you live in the neighborhood or if you drop in. It's a staple that must be experienced.
author: Laura G.

description: This is our "fish-place".  When we want seafood, we typically don't go anywhere else, and there's a reason for that.  In a nutshell, it's a nice, low-key, fairly unpretentious, reasonably priced neighborhood spot.  Its got a nice atmosphere, dimly lit, candle-light, nice artwork on the walls, chill/jazzy music.  And, most importantly, the food is always good.  I've never had a bad or poorly cooked entree.  I particularly like the variety of sauces involved with ordering your fish.  You can choose from I believe up to 4 different types of sauces, and you choose the method its prepared (sauteed, blackened, etc).  It's a cool little neighborhood spot, nice place to take a date.  Really no complaints with this place, good food, good people, good atmosphere.
author: Zach J.

description:
EXTREMELY poor service.  Despite having made a reservation, there was no table ready for us when my girlfriend and I arrived (we were even ten minutes early for the reservation).  Forgivable perhaps -- until a walk-in couple was seated at the next table that became available -- even before those of us with a reservation.

We then waited another fifteen minutes for a table, which finally became available after the maitre d' cleared a recently-vacated, four-top table and split it into two.  Yet while we were waiting, a buddy of the maitre d' arrived and was seated not only at the same time as us, but at the far better table -- I say far better because our table was not even capable of use: it was so close to the tables lining the nearby wall that I could not even pull my chair up to the table without literally sitting on top of the individual dining next to us.

I informed the maitre d' that the table was unacceptable and that I was truly disappointed with the service, yet -- despite acknowledging the table was unusable -- he nevertheless suggested I was somehow at fault for having only made a reservation about an hour prior to my arrival (!).    When I pointed out that it was his restaurant that GAVE ME THE RESERVATION (indeed, that's the whole point of having a reservation) he had no real response.  He also had no real response when I pointed out that his friend who arrived twenty minutes after us was seated at the same time (and at an actual, usable table).  At that point, we left.

I found this experience truly unfortunate because I've eaten at Alamo Square before and had a pleasant experience.  But now, I suggest not wasting your time here.  If I could rate this restaurant below one star, I would.
author: Steven K.

description: Fish is very fresh and the atmosphere is cozy, however the service is lackluster.  Have been here twice and each time the service was slow and entree's not served for all diners at the same time.  No fun to have others in your party politely wait for you to get served while their food gets cold.  The last visit the waiter was also bussing tables.  They need a better service system - wouldn't mind paying a $ or 2 more for better service.
author: Mark N.

description: Alamo Square Seafood Grill was on par New Year's Eve.  For an extremely reasonable price they offered a five course dinner (under $60 per person).  The restaurant is small and laid out a bit on the snug side.  the servers and host are attentive and entertaining.  The food came out a comfortable pace, nothing was rushed, and waiting was not an issue.  The beef carpaccio melts in the mouth.  The gnocchi was perfectly cooked and deliciously creamy.  The fish had the perfect flaky crispiness to the outside.  The flourless chocolate cake was the surprise of the night.  Everything on the plate was well presented, warm, and thoughtfully prepared.  This is definitely a place well worth a return visit.
author: Stephanie S.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in SF and perfect for dates. Sometimes the service can be a bit slow, but the food is delicious and reasonably priced.
author: E S.

description: came in here with a group. We started with the pate and calamari. The pate was nothing to write home about. the calamari were pretty good but nothing great. I had the snapper, blackened, with provencal sauce. The fish and sauce were great, the rice was extraneous. Good to know that they at least know how to cook fish in a fish house. However, when I ordered coffee and then brought out a stone cold cup of coffee, they lost any chance at getting anything of a good number of stars. yes, they brewed up another pot real quick, but really, that is pretty damn bad. fish aside, the experience here was lacking. maybe if i lived in the neighborhood I would give it another chance, but it is too far out of the way to bother
author: Rich B.

description: I have to admit- I read a ton of reviews about this place before I went. And I was scared.  But, I had a great experience here- and to be honest, I don't even really like fish. I went on a Saturday evening with my husband and Mom and we were greeted, seated and fed in quick succession. The fish was fresh, tasty and I liked the fact that you can select your own sauce and prep method. Cute candle-lit atmosphere and a nice neighborhood vibe.
author: Dana K.

description: We once loved the delicious and charming Alamo Square Seafood Grill... not so much anymore. We went for mother's day dinner and had a pretty awful experience all around. They only had one waitress for the entire restaurant, whose only role, it seemed, was to take our order. The busboy, dishwasher and even chef picked up most of the work - running dishes, clearing plates, filling water, etc. Even so, everything was excruciatingly slow and all the food came out room temperature or cold. The scallops were too salty, the mashed potatoes tasted like they were out of a box and they were out of two types of the very limited beer selection.   We were really disappointed with most of the evening and hoped they would have gone the extra mile for a special occasion.
author: Melissa W.

description:
this was my friend's farewell dinner before she bounced for Thailand.  the meal was not terrible, but not great either.  the waiter was attentive despite being the only one working this night.  

we ordered the crab cakes to start off, and these were simply average.   what really made me unhappy was the fact that all 3 steaks were overcooked!  we specified medium rare but they ALL came out well done.   it wasn't even close.  

to close out, i had the tiramisu which was dee-licious.  the other desserts seemed to satisfy the rest of the gang.  I wouldn't rule out coming here again, but i would try the seafood instead of another over cooked steak.
author: Danny W.

description:
They've been around for 10 years now, and I feel like this restaurant either needs to step up to the plate or just leave.

Last time I dined they served cold bernaise sauce, crap pate and the staff acted like preparing food was an immense hassle.  Previous excursions have been pleasant, though, so I am wondering if they're just tired of the restaurant business.

Either get more interesting (ie:  with flavor, nothing frozen in the middle, moules frites that didnt sit too long) or just get out.
author: M M.

description: This is  good, fresh seafood at a reasonable price. It was a very basic fish and vegetables combo done well. The only thing I didn't like about it was that the waiter  seemed annoyed by the fact that he had to wait on us. I thought the escargot was greasy (would not recommend), but everything else was pretty good.
author: mazzy s.

description: Stopped by this place just because it looked cute from the outside.  Limited menu and they were out of their specials, but I ordered the Tuna (which I've never had good luck with) and it was outstanding.  Even my friend who doesn't like fish loved it.  Prices were fair, atmosphere was good, service was pleasant.  Please update your website, it still has Valentine's Day listed.
author: Loralyn S.

description: I've been wanting to try this restaurant for some time.One friend told me it was really nice and driving by it looks very euro quaint. So I finally made a reservation one night. 35 minutes after our reservation time, we inquired about table. We were told there is no way to know how much longer of a wait. After 50 minutes past our reservation, we again were told there was no way to know. The response to "why do you bother taking reservations" was no restaurant in the city can guarantee you will get a table even with a reservation" I guess at that point we were the fools for sticking around that long.
author: Heather M.

description:
This is one of my very favorite restaurants. The mussels and the fresh fish are delicious (my favorite is the salmon with beurre blanc), and the one time I decided to branch out and get a steak it was very tasty, too. They have a variety of wines, including several that are very reasonably priced and delicious, or BYOB on Wednesday.

The service here isn't fast, but you really shouldn't rush your way through a meal like this anyway. The atmosphere here is nice, so come ready to relax with a glass of wine and maybe sip on one of the soup samples they sometimes pass out. Every time I've come, the staff have been perfectly pleasant, helping us find the best wine for our food and stopping by to see how everything tastes.

The overall atmosphere at Alamo is classy yet relaxed. I really enjoy that it offers delicious food at a reasonable price in an environment that's very pleasant without trying too hard to be chic.
author: Joanna L.

description: Miss this place and you'll miss something really amazing - seafood prepared with flavor and texture beyond description, and what has to be the best dining value in San Francisco!  There were six in our party, and arriving with our reservations at 6:30 on Friday evening the restaurant was empty.  As we proceeded through our meal, however, it filled rather quickly.  Some of us ordered from the prix fixe menu, which I found to be the best value, because of the inclusion of a salad and dessert.  Look - just put ASSG on your "Must Dine Here" list (unless you don't like seafood, in which case why are you reading this review?) and go enjoy!  Todd was a gracious and appreciative host (he said he doesn't read restaurant reviews but would look for mine), and the total experience was unforgettable!  Dress is casual, but don't show up looking poorly dressed and embarrass yourself.  Now - get over there!
author: Mike M.

description:
I guess we should start with the service.  They are greatly understaffed- there was one waitress and a man, who was a host/server and probably the owner.  With just two people working the entire restaurant the service was slow.  The man was the one who served us and he had an arrogance about him that made me and my family feel like a bunch of idiots.  Especially when describing the wine- as though all we'd ever had was a box of Franzia.  The little sample of tomato soup and the "French" onion soup we had before our main courses were both very salty and incredibly rich.  Getting our entrees took forever, actually the waiter took our silverware away at one point thinking we had already eaten.  When we stopped him and told him we had to receive to our entrees he looked very surprised.  The atmosphere was so loud.  

The place was packed and so it was really bustling, but if that wasn't enough they were blaring 80's pop.  (Really fitting for a dark French bistro.)  We were also seated right behind the kitchen and so on top of the natural noise of the tables, the pop music there were dishes being slammed around (twice something broke) and an annoying chopping noise that sounded more like a hammer.

Finally the food came out about 45mins after we ordered and it was room temperature- not very hot at all.  I got the scallop special with a blue crab potato puree, a charred tomato, a cream sauce and watercress dressed across the top.  It was pretty good, but there did seem to be too much going on, on the plate. Simpler sides and lighter sauce would have been better.  So overall it was okay but little did I know that, that was not the end of my dining experience! When I got home I had a terrible stomachache and had a lot of trouble sleeping.  I attribute it  and my throwing up THREE times that night to the slightly undercooked, luke warm scallops. So for all that I give it one star, I mean at least they tried.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I used to come to this place often since it's located right around the corner from my house. However in the last few years, the service has become so awful that I've decided to stop patronizing this little joint. The hair challenged receptionist/waiter is so rude that it feels like he's doing you a favor letting you in. Once you're seated, the service tends to be terrible although a few times it was just bearable.

When it comes to the food, they have an interesting way to marinate your fish selection if that's what you like. However I doubt the fish is really fresh. Everything tastes more or less as if it was just taken out of the freezer and warmed up for you (think Olive Garden). For years, this place used to be a bargain with fish entrees around $12. However they have raised the prices in the last couple of years. Now it's not a bargain anymore AND the food is mediocre. 

All in all, it's a fairly miserable dining experience. If you live in the immediate area, I recommend venturing a few blocks down to Hayes Valley or a few blocks up to Divisidero street where they have great restaurant selections. Just skip this place!
author: Phil G.

description: came by here for a casual sunday night dinner after a long day in the sun.  we didn't really have anything particular in mind, and remembered passing by this place a few weeks ago.  very glad we dropped by,.  what i really loved is the neighborhoody feel to this restaurant.  it was very intimate and comfortable inside and was definitely not crowded (i always appreciate places in the city where you don't have to make a reservation 8 years in advance).  they seated us at a very comfortable corner table (there is a long, padded bench on either side of the restaurant lined with two tops, so with the corner table, both people can sit on the bench and be cozy).  service was very prompt, and the waiter was very helpful in answering all of our questions and letting us taste the wines before deciding.  all the food we ordered was delicious, and the prices were extremely reasonable and the portions were just right.  the prix fixe before 7:00 is definitely a good deal.
author: Ash T.

description:
Returned to Alamo with husband and father-in-law yesterday and had an even better experience than last time! Sorry to read that other Yelpers had issues with the service- on both occasions, we've gone on Sunday at 5-530pm when they've just opened and we've always had an attentive hostess. The place is as cute as we remember and once again, I had the prix fixe menu- a cup of clam chowder (so good- I'm really picky about my chowder and Alamo's is awesome!) and a nice portion of blackened snapper with a peppercorn sauce. I seriously almost licked my plate afterwards! You should definitely try the heirloom tomato salad- fresh and flavorful. My floating island desert still pleased and my husband's summer berry trifle was refreshing.

Would totally come back here again! Would recommend this restaurant to anyone wanting a cozy dinner with great food, reasonable prices!
author: Bao N.

description: Food is dee-lish.  And even though I felt prepared for slow, poor, inattentive service (I'd read all about it on Yelp), I was scarcely prepared for just how bad.  The slowness of the service would not be uncommon abroad  and were it London or Barcelona, it would not bother me.  Fair or not, stateside, this level of service is unacceptable.
author: Alexia J.

description: I came here last night with my hubby and our best friends in the city. We had a great time. The food was really good, not the best seafood I've ever had, but definitely delicious. I got the beet/goat cheese salad and the bouillabaise. Unfortunately, we were there after the prix fixe deal had ended for the evening, but the prices were still very reasonable. The atmosphere was cozy and neighbohood-y. The service was pretty slow, but it didn't matter because we were not in a hurry and were having fun drinking wine while we waited. Plus the staff made up for it by being super friendly and accomodating. Overall it was a very enjoyable experience.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I've been here several times, and I've never been disappointed.
Their food is always outstanding, their prices are reasonable, and the service is always friendly.

As several other reviewers have mentioned, they have a prix fixe menu which is even more reasonable (practically a steal), and it is always prepared with the same quality as the rest of the items from their menu.

The prix fixe menu selection changes from day to day, which may cause a cynic to suggest that the prix fixe menu is a method for liquidating surplus ingredients. While it's entirely possible (and a reasonable business practice no less), you would never know it from the quality of the food. Everything I have eaten here has always shown great quality of ingredients and great attention to preparation.
author: Gregg K.

description:
in the small, local, delicious and reasonable category - this is one of the best in the city.  great food, great BYOW on wednesday.  save room for dessert (or dont and order it anyway!) 

Awesome.
author: David F.

description: Cutting right to the chase: the food was exceptional. Not perfect...for example, the crab cake appetizer was a tad too moist. However, such details were very minor compared to the overall excellence, including aroma, flavor, texture, portions, and presentation. The place has a comfortable atmosphere with friendly wait staff. The service could have been more professional, but their good attitude almost made up for it. If you want a relaxed and warm atmosphere and fantastic seafood at moderate prices, you won't do much better than Alamo Square Seafood Grill.
author: Ash B.

description: I love the fact the we can choose the fish, how it's being cooked and the sauce to go with it and their price is better than we thought for being in the city.  We had the Smoke Salmon salad and Escargots Farcies as the appetizers and they both were great!  The fish we had were great, no complains.  The tiramisu was a bit of a disappointment but my kir royale made up for it.  This place is great for a romantic dinner but maybe too small for big party.
author: Sonia H.

description: Ech! The soup was cold and uninteresting. The tuna was raw and tough. The steak was tough and too salty. And the service was atrocious.
author: Saul F.

description:
Nice little bistro in this historic part of town, that was the perfect place for a meeting with my friends!  We started with a grilled spicy shrimps flatbread  (good for 2 pers) , mix green salad and mussels mariniere, all was very good.Then I had the flank steak served with fries and fresh spinach. Everyone was very happy about their dishes and we had a good laugh with Todd the waiter, very witty fellow. It was busy but he took the time to describe beautifully all specials. Good wine and music selection , overall very affordable casual place.
This bistro is perfect for a romantic evening or bigger parties. We will go back !!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Great neighborhood date spot! We sat at the table in the front window and had a romantic, quiet dinner.  This was on a Friday night.  I thought that the service was warm and attentive.  I believe that it was the Chef or Chef-Owner who waited on us (he mentioned that he makes the bouillabaisse himself) as well as a friendly server who was clearly very busy, but not neglecting her guests.  We were not rushed, the pace was perfect and the food was delicious. The PEI moules frites were perfectly prepared; we practically drank the broth and the fires were hot and very crisp and even served in a little cone of parchment.   I loved the delicate saffron broth of the Bouillabaisse and my boyfriend had the grilled Mahi special.  It's definitely a great little space for a romantic dinner.   This place is totally charming and truly San Francisco.
author: R G.

description: Went here with the girls last night and had a wonderful time!!!  I had the snapper (which I loved) , my friend had the salmon (which she loved)... there were six of us and I think everyone was pretty happy with what they got.  Todd our server was funny and helpful even gave out some "love" advice.  We missed the pre-fix dinner but the price was still really good for the amount of food and the number of people in our group!  Had a great time.  I think the food always tastes good with great girl friends and wine!  Thanks again Todd for a good evening!  I'll be back!!!!
author: Jodi B.

description: It's a quaint place where you have the choice in ordering what type of fish you want with what type of sauce and how you want your fish prepared. The fish is fresh but I didn't think it was that flavorful. It could have been my fish and sauce combo, but I left the place rather un-fulfilled although my wallet was happy that I didn't spend too much on a fare that was only mediocre.
author: Janel Y.

description:
This place is a quaint little escape from the projects.  The price is just right for the wine and the food.  I had the special, which was a trio of oddly matched foods, yet madly delicious.  The special of the evening was braised short ribs, seared ahi tuna or salmon, and risotto.
Another menu item that interested me was the selection of fresh fish prepared according to your desire.
The dessert was disappointing.  The creme brulee trio was not pleasing.  I recommend the lemon tart if you have a sweet tooth like me.
Overall, this is a nice neighborhood spot.  A tastier dessert would have yielded a fourth star.  I'll give it another chance, hopefully I will be pleased and perhaps my review will show another star.
author: Ashley Q.

description: I've eaten here a few times and have always left satisfied.  Their reasonably priced fish is very fresh and I like how you can get it grilled, sauteed, blackened, or poached.  I always get it grilled.  I think so far I've tried the swordfish, mahimahi, and the trout.  All were perfectly cooked and melted in my mouth.  You can also choose what sauce to pair with it!  Buere Blanc is my fav.  Yummy!  Wednesdays are free corkage night which is a plus.  Oh! They also have a prix fix menu-chef's choice only.  For $15 you get soup or salad, entree, and dessert.  If you get there early like we do you may get a free appetizer prepared by chef Lance himself.
author: anne m.

description:
Interesting to see differing opinions on a place, but I come here all the time, love it and have done for years. Was there recently and had baked gnocchi, the wife had scallops (both from the chalkboard), and they were amazing. Warm bread salad to start with, a well recommended bottle of wine... and we had another good night.

I feel sorry for the folks that have had a bad one in here. I'm served great food, regularly and at a decent price.
author: Jon G.

description:
This restaurant is around the corner from my apartment, and I was wary of going there at first because it was covered by a scaffolding, and I just couldn't see what it looked like inside.  But, I went last night (Wednesday nights have no corkage fee!), and had a great meal for around $50 for two.  Not bad.  The food was solid - the bread and pesto dip was great, and they came out with a curry soup taste that was delicious.  Then we had two appetizers - the escargot was great, while the other dish, which I forget the name of, had scallops and mushrooms in a kind of casserole, was not very good.  It's not on the online menu, so maybe it's an experiment that hopefully won't last long.  I had the seafood stew for my main course, which was great, although not what was advertised (I was told it would be in a tomato broth and involved mussels, prawns, crab, fish, and calamari, and it was in a white wine/garlic broth and didn't include crab at all).  My dinner partner had blackened snapper, and it was great.  All and all, it's a great meal for a great price and I would definitely go back.

UPDATE: So, I went back, and I will now never be back.  Service was terrrriiible!  And the food wasn't that good this time (I had the gnocchi - not good at all, which isn't totally fair because I HATE parsley, and this dish was covered in it, but still).  My friends had tuna and the snapper and said it was just okay - not worth the pain of the lack of service.

If they would just hire another waitress, maybe they'd be okay, but I really don't like having to work every single time to get the waitress's attention, when the place isn't even that full.  Totally spoiled the experience for me, and I'm not going back - there are plenty of beter seafood places out there.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I like to go here since its a small neighborhood restaurant that serves fish the way you like it -- the wednesday no corkage is a great incentive to bring a big group of friends and take up the entire evening.  Overall, the service was great -- on times with just a table for two and with a big group.  I don't think the food is anything to rave about, but it is cooked simply and consistently.  My one exception is the time I ordered the swordfish -- a weekday special -- and hated it.  Perhaps I'm not a swordfish kind of gal, but it still hasn't stopped me from returning.  Its often packed (even on weekdays), so you know the fish has to be super fresh...
author: Lisa C.

description:
We had a great meal here last night! I wanted to find a local place to take my Grandma and sister before heading over to Beach Blanket Babylon, and my friend suggested this great little spot 3 blocks from my house. We got there at 6:45 and they seemed surprised we didn't have a reservation, but the place did fill up as we were eating. I had the special - petrole sole with a lemon-caper sauce, haricots verts and almonds and vegetable polenta, and it was awesome! The polenta was especially delicious - I couldn't stop eating it. I'd never had sole before, but it was prepared wonderfully and the sauce was fantastic. My grandmother ordered the crab cakes as a main dish instead of an appetizer, and really enjoyed them (she thought they were a bit too peppery, but still great, and I actually thought they were the best ones I'd ever had. I don't usually like them, but I liked these! Probably because they had lobster in them), and my sister had the vegetarian dish (gnocchi with tons of veggies). We also shared the flourless chocolate cake and a huckleberry-strawberry-apple crisp, both ala mode - yum! With all that, three coffees, and three glasses of wine, the bill (before tip) came out to only $90. Oh, and they also brought us a little amuse bouche (ha! doesn't that make you think of that Friends episode with Jon Lovitz? Well, it is amus-ing!) of a very yummy and interesting white bean soup in a little espresso cup before we ordered, as well as bread with an interesting pesto-ish dipping sauce. The service was also awesome - we had two people (a male and a female) waiting on us who were both  very friendly and attentive, took our coats, and were happy to call a cab for us at the end of the meal. Great place - I can't wait to go back!

Oh, one other thing - it's got a very nice, but very dimly-lit ambiance, so my sister and I had to hold up our cell phones so my grandmother could read the menu. If you have trouble reading in low light, bring a flashlight!
author: Janet G.

description: This is a fantastic restaurant in a semi-sketchy neighborhood (surrounded by projects). They always have an excellent seafood variety which can be cooked various ways with different kinds of sauces. The prices are reasonable, and service is always efficient, although I must admit, the waiter could be friendlier. Or perhaps the "Charles Bronson" demeanor is part of the charm? Everything said and done, this is a must try for anyone that loves good seafood.
author: Matin N.

description:
My wife and I went here last night.  She's been trying to get me to go for quite some time, and I must say, I'm kicking myself for not eating here sooner!  This is a wonderfully unpretentious, romantic little neighborhood gem where you can enjoy a flavorful meal with quality ingredients at a reasonable price.

The wine list is predominately French, which I am not well versed in, being a California Snob.  However, there were quite a few bottles in the $30 range, and when we asked our server to recommend something, he was quite helpful and didn't try to upsell anything (We settled on a delicious Pinot Gris from Alsace for $35).

As for the food, it was all great.  We shared the crab cakes which were as good as any I've had in the city.  My wife ordered the chicken, and while I generally refuse to ever order chicken when we're out, I think I'll have to make a permanent exception for Alamo Square.  The dish was so succulent!

I ordered the cassoulet, having never had this dish before.  This was on their special list, so I can't vouch for it being available in the future.  However, I was really delighted in the subtle flavor of the duck, white beans, sausage, and tomato sauce.

We closed out with a little Port and Espresso, and the evening was a resounding delight!

I hope you enjoy it as much as we did!
author: Brian S.

description: An amazing value. I got the prix fixe special and was amazed by the quality and quantity of food for the price ($13.50!). The dessert was a little weird (a meringue surround by creme anglaise...not something I'd prepare for the masses), but beyond that, the salad and main course were delicious and fresh. I opted for the fixed price to be able to taste a bit of everything, but the menu is cheap enough that I wouldn't necessarily order it again. I would love to go back and try additional fish selections as well as their crab cake.
author: Beth T.

description:
This place is right around the corner from me.  It's a good place if you pick the prix fixe menu, but there are two things wrong with it.

The first thing is that the desserts are weak.  This is actually surprising, as it takes a lot to make me unhappy with anything with sugar on top... but they've managed it.  Soggy and tasteless meringue thingy.

The second thing is that the service is... well, french.  There's just no other way to put it.  If you need to get out of there fast, your best bet is to grab a server by the ear and hold him until he agrees to give you the check, and pay cash so you don't have to wait for the credit card to come back.

Other than that, no complaints.
author: Will S.

description: Great place. Intimate, cozy, great combo of portions and price. Dishes were tasteful, sophisticated yet modestly understated. I highly recommed doing the prixe fixe on the weekend - three courses plus a starter, compliments of the chef, for about $14 or so. And on a nice day, you can take the scenic walk through Alamo Square to get to your din-din.
author: Clar L.

description: Enjoyable dining experience every time. I like how you can choose the type, preparation, and sauce for the fish. I love the warm, wooden feel of the restaurant. It's a perfect date spot..
author: Chris S.

description: I like this place, but I also live around the corner.  So, I'm probably a bit more forgiving.  They have no corkage fees on Wednesday and a great prix fix from Sun - Thur ($12.50).  The food is good, mostly seafood, but the steak frites are yummy as well.  The owner changed, and the food has vastly improved.  They do need to work on service.  Everything took forever, and the 2 people were running around.  Its' definitely reasonably priced even outside of the prix fix.  I would say it's a great neighborhood joint, but not necessarily a destination spot.
author: Liz C.

description: One word, excellent.  Took my parents their for a birthday celebration before the theatre and we were all impressed.  Various selections for fish and sauces that you can mix and match to your taste.  A good bottle of wine, the cozy atmosphere, and the outstanding prices leave only the parking to be desired.  Two thumbs up!!!
author: Angela D.

description: Been here twice for Dinner over the holidays and both times I enjoyed it immensely. The perfect menu. Not so large that you're inundated with so many options that your head hurts yet something for everyone. Great wine list. Stellar ambience and the service was impeccable.
author: Clint A.

description:
i've been to alamo square several times over the past 5 years or so. it hasn't changed too much in that time. it's basically an OK French seafood bistro. it's run by local Frenchies, so the service is a little slower than most Americans would expect. 

the standard menu is pretty basic- pick a fish, pick a prep, pick a sauce. the specials are definitely more interesting, but i haven't had anything there that blew my mind.    

on the plus side, the floor staff hasn't changed much, and the owner is there more often than not, so they'll remember you and you'll feel welcomed and comfortable.   

oh! as a promotion, they're doing BYOB wednesdays with no corkage fee. plus, they've got parking for when your friends come to meet you from other 'hoods.
author: alex j.

description: You can not beat the price!  If you like dessert avoid the price fixed, it comes with a odd dessert.  Food is average, had a great salad and a typical crab cake.  Slightly slow service, but still very friendly.
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
2 stars for the food. The food is good! I don't even want to go into the reasons I will never go back.

OK.... So I went back, and it was much better than the last time. The food is really good here, and relatively inexpensive.
author: Brian O.

description: My favorite little bistro in the city.  The service can be a little slow at times, but I prefer to think of it as "French."  Decent wine selection, and OUTSTANDING fresh fish.  My strategy is to pick the kind of fish I want and let the chef decide which preparation will be best.  I haven't been led astray yet!
author: Heather M.

description: Good fish dishes.  Not the best, but good.  The appetizers are pretty good.  Go on Wednesdays because there is no corkage fee for wine.  Its a nice intimate setting as well.
author: Dishar R.

description: Close your eyes and you'll swear you're in a little seafood bistro in France. When the bill comes, you'll be pleasantly surprised that you're not paying French bistro prices. And, you'll make this your regular SF spot for seafood.
author: Sara B.

description: I usually really like this place. We went their for New Year's eve so they had the prix fix menu.  Which was fine, it was a deal compared to alot of other places in the city.  But the portions were a little ridiculously small for some of the courses, or maybe they just weren't described very accurately on the menu. The service, which is usually very good, was very, very slow.  When we were there it wasn't all that busy yet either. But anyway...when I am there on a normal night I almost always order one of their grilled fish specials and share their typcially amazing soup as an appetizer. I will go again, I hope next time I am Wowed a little bit to make up for New Year's.
author: Kathleen Y.

description: Ok,  this place is a  freaking neighborhood gem! NO CORKAGE FEE ON WEDNSDAYS!!! Holy crap-o-lee! And they have a $14.50 three course prix fixe dinner from 5:30 to 7pm every day but Wednesdays. So there has to be a catch right? Wrong. It's just damn good food without all the fuss and frivolity that this town tends to lean towards. Seafood options vary nightly and you tell them how you want it cooked. Straightforward, good food at a super reasonable price. Don't really know why everyone is ripping on the service, ours was excellent, attentive and timed right. The dining room is small so best for dates or double dates. My wife and I are making this a once a month night out for us, and easy to get to from the Richmond...it's right off the 5 bus line. MMM. Two snaps.
author: Sky C.

description: Food was delicious.  I'm partial to Ahi Tuna, and they prepared it well, with a delicious glaze.  My wife enjoyed the red snapper.  The flourless chocolate cake for dessert was excellent.  Ambience is nice.  My only complaint, albeit a minor one, is that since the space is small, the tables are crammed very close together.
author: Steve W.

description: I was here on a Friday night and I must say that everyone enjoyed their dining experience.  I had the Pan Fried trout with a Bernaisse sauce...mmmmmm....   The price was great at $13.50 and my share was under $20 with tax/tip.  I was however able to try their escargot, and some of my friends' other dishes which was again ..yum...  If you do splurge for the apps, drinks, and dessert, watch out.... your bill will definitely approach the $40-50 range.
author: Belayet K.

description: Really enjoyed dinner here a few months ago.  Felt like a true Parisian bistro.  Love, love, love the no corkage on Wednesday. But what is truly wonderful is the food. My friend and I both enjoyed our fish entrees and there were so many choices of sauce and preparation.  I'll definitely be returning.
author: Donna K.

description: I am always pleased after eating at this restaurant. The seafood is spectacular. We tried the oysters this time and oh my gosh they were amazing. The sauce they were served in was unique and delicious. It is one of my top favorite restaurants in the city. I highly recommend the experience.
author: Jessica B.

description: One of my fav spots for seafood. Everything is fresh daily. You have your choice of fish, how you would like it prepared, and what sauce you would like. I like blackened with the bearnaise. Price-fixe menu from 5:30-7 daily - chef's choice of entree, soup/salad and dessert for $14.50. Corkage is $10 so bring a bottle of your favorite wine and enjoy oh and don't forget the trio of creme brulees - awesome!
author: Maria M.

description:
I went here for my 25th birthday and it was perhaps the best food I've ever eaten on my birthday. It was extremely fresh fare with well blended seasonings. Our group tried the tuna, trout, and salmon and all were excellent. The appetizers were delicious and the fish was cooked to perfection. Although you can easily spend a fortune here, if you go for their fish "platter" that's around $14 you get an insane bargain. 

Reservations are recommended but we got there early and the friendly staff sat us without one.

The Western Addition isn't my favorite place to hang out but it was well worth the trip.
author: Bob B.

description:
Ate here this past Saturday.  We ordered

Appetizers:
mussels: real good
