pate: different from what i'm used to and I couldn't taste the flavors
clam chowder: pretty good. better than ur average chain restaurant
calamari: decent

Entrees:
I had the pork with veggies.  It was pretty good.  Not as juicy as I would like.  A bit difficult to cut but the meat wasn't dry.  

They had the rack of lamb as a special.  It was okay.  Basque has better rack of lamb and the portion is bigger.

Dessert: the portions are extremely small except for the creme burlee.
Special: chocolate cake,  nothing special. about 2"x2" piece
Tiramisu: Definitely had better.
Creme Burlee: Yummy. love the top
Apple tart:  Soft but the crust could be tastier.

Reservations definitely recommended since the place is small and dinner is a two hour ordeal.  Definitely recommend ordering appetizer to quench the hunger because it's like  a 20-30 min wait for appetizer and another 20-30 min wait between apps and entree.
author: Kazoua T.

description: Had a wonderful experience during Dine For Life night at this place last night.  I can't believe I've lived here 11 years and never been here.  Small, cute, quaint.  Friendly service, good food (with one miss - mussels and frites don't live up to their potential), nice wine choices and prices.  Will be back for the BYO Wednesdays.
author: e w.

description: Nice, quiet little neighborhood spot.  The food was very good and the prices are very reasonable.  Service was solid.  Good for a date, friends or family.
author: Daniel B.

description:
The food was delicious.  All of us enjoyed our appetizers and entrees.  A dining companion highly recommends the corn and crab chowder. 

However, the service was much too slow.  It took over 10 minutes just to be greeted, and nearly 1/2 hour after finishing our entrees before the hostess or waiter (yes, there was only one waiter for the entire restaurant) to check back with us.

The food was excellent, but you can get the same quality with better service somewhere else.
author: Rolo B.

description: I went to Alamo Square Seafood Grill on Sunday and was very impressed. There was one college age student, running the place, and even though it was really busy, she kept a smile on her face. I think her name was Ruth, but I could be wrong. The food was delicious, the welcoming service and the cute SF atmosphere make this place an A! thanks Ruth and seafood grill! nice work!
author: Carlotta W.

description: To begin with, woefully understaffed. I ordered the $12.50 special (offered Sunday through Thursday and Friday and Saturday early evenings) and the result was average at best. The paprika dusted halibut was just OK, the side vegetables a bit mushy and drowning in butter and the rice pilaf I could've made at home. The worst, however, were the mussels, which we had to send back because about a third of the shellfish hadn't opened (an invitation for food poisoning). Kudos, however, to the delicious crab cake appetizer and the healthy pouring of wine. If I lived in the neighborhood I might go back; otherwise there's far better choices in the city--even if the price is right.
author: David K.

description:
Luckily for me this place is about 10 yards from my door step.  

I had a delicious Wednesday night dinner here.  This night is great because you can bring your own bottle of wine with you.

I had the dinner special - seared ahi tuna on a bed of sweet corn risotto with braised radicchio.  Delicious!!!

Wonderful atmosphere and great candle lighting.  So happy its so close to my house
author: Angela C.

description:
-1/2 star for the really salty hollandaise sauce 
-1/2 star for the dessert (avoid the floating island)

It was close to closing time when we arrived and the place was on the quiet side. I tried escargots for the first time and really enjoyed it. Great value for the portions, 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, 1 dessert, 1 bottle of wine for a little under $100.
author: B N.

description: Not bad! We went here on a Saturday night around 8pm.  No problem getting a reservation an hour before.    Had the escargot and pate for appetizer and both got the seared tuna special for entree with a really nice french savignon blanc.  Pretty inexpensive for the quality of the food.
author: Paul M.

description: I was there for the first time last night and I'll definitely be back. What a treat! A casual, European ambience (I felt like I was in St. Germain des Près), excellent, attentive service, and above all, exquisite food. My sea bass was superb and my friends raved about their New York steaks. The mussels are the best I've had in years, and I know mussels! Check this place out, you won't regret it.
author: Paul T.

description: So, I went on a Wed. and still no corkage charge. The prix fixe price is $14.50, and on that night, the entree was mussel stew. The available fish that evening was trout, salmon and red snapper. I chose the blackenend snapper. It came with cous cous and broiled zucchini cubes. I have to say, the portions were not HUGE, as I thought they would be and tasted ok, but not spectacular. Service was pretty good, although they were overwhelmed by the crowds on my night.
author: Henry M.

description: My wife and I love this place! I think its one of the best deals in the city. You get great food in a great atmosphere at a great price! Always get the fish or one of the specials. These guys know what they're doing and they do it well! And you gotta love Wed. nights with no corkage fee!
author: CHRIS R.

description:
We chose this place because of the good reviews. The beginning was promising. We were promptly seated. Menu items were explained and order was taken. Then came the wait. We have to ask multiple times to have water filled. When we finished our entrees (Salmon tartare, fish soup - 3.5 stars for both), it took us a full 20 minutes and three reminders to get the check - the service staff were not rude, they just completely ignored us. Maybe because there were just the two of us, and I didn't drink, for I observed that the bigger and drinking parties around us got their water refilled and checks delivered. Maybe because we were obviously first time out-of-towners (they asked while seating us). Maybe because there were only two of them on a Friday night in a full house. I don't know the exact reason for the very slow service, but I do know that the food is not good enough to get me to go back to this place. The restaurant may be nice for dating, but only if you don't mind seating with empty water glasses and trying to find things to talk about while waiting for the check that just doesn't come.

Oh, one hour after the meal, my husband got food poisoning... Definitely not going back!
author: Ginger J.

description:
First of all, our waitress (name began with an L) was awesome. She helped to direct us to some of the tastier items on the menu and away from things that weren't as great. She was patient with our group of eight and came by to check on us often enough.

The free-BYO Wednesday was a great way to spend time with friends. Eight people, six bottles of wine, multiple appetizers, wonderful entrees for all, desserts... we all walked away feeling like we had eaten a far more expensive dinner than it actually cost us.

I got one of the "fish specialties" which meant that I selected a type of fish, cooking method and sauce. Snapper, poached in provencale sauce. I was happy. The risotto and veggies were also excellent. I tasted some of the grilled tuna, which was left nicely raw in the middle, kind of seared.

Aweome waitress hooked us up with two excellent desserts - fresh strawberry shortcake. The shortcake tasted like it had come out of the oven just a few minutes prior and the strawberries were sweet and perfect. Creme brulee had that wonderful burnt (in a good way, people, we're talking brulee...) top that made me want to roast marshmellows.

It'd be five stars if it was always sans-corkage. Unfortunately, that's just a Wednesday phenomonon.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Had a bad night here tonight-- have had really great experiences and prices, esp. on BYOB wine night.  However, tonight they only had one frazzled waiter working the entire restaurant, calamari was literally fried rings with no seafood in them, and we had to wait 20 mins for our reservation time.  Also the creme brulee had like ten thousand pounds of sugar on it and they effed up our credit card transactions. 

I hope they read this because I want it to go back to the way it was! Just because you have a BYOB night doesn't mean you can slack off...
author: Alex B.

description: Since I'm a regular here I think the service is fine. And I'm a regular because the food is great - My husband usually gets the special of the day and I always get my own special Grilled Salmon with french fries and bernaise (they make the best fries!)- and the prices are right. We've also been having a special salad with smoked trout that is too die for. Sometimes when they are busy it gets a little slow, but as long as my wine glass gets filled I'm happy!
author: Rebecca R.

description: Awesome! I went here with a group of seven friends on a Wednesday night and they treated us so well. No corkage fee and really amazing food and even better service. Then, I somehow managed to forget my wallet in our seat and didn't notice until after they had closed, I frantically called and they answered and stayed around late into the night until I was able to come and pick up my wallet, Amazing! Really, what other place in San Francisco would do that? There isn't a better place in town to bring your parents, a date, or a group of friends. I'll go back and recommend this place to anyone.
author: Britt C.

description: i was hopeful that this place would be good since it's 2 blocks from home and i love seafood. alas, i won't be going there again anytime soon. the prices are reasonable but the food is nothing more than ordinary. less than ordinary by SF standards. my friend ordered a tuna steak that was cooked white all the way through. that about says it all.
author: Brett W.

description: A reviewer referred to this as a 'gay' restaurant, which I find amusing. What is it, exactly, that makes her think it's gay? Certainly not the cuisine, since I don't think food has a sexual preference one way or the other, although anything with a French name tends to sound suspiciously sissy. (Say that five times fast and you'll sound like a sissy yourself.) The waiters? I think the accents may be giving a wrong impression. I've been here twice, and both times the clientele was mixed, so it's not the people patronizing the place. Whatever, I've given it a couple of tries and wasn't impressed enough to return again, gay, straight, or fashionably bi. In fact, my last time here was particularly unpleasant. Pardonnez-moi, monsieur, I realize you're French, but you're working in America, so could you slap a little deodorant on your pits, s'il vous plait, so I don't have to breathe through my mouth?
author: Gourmet G.

description:
three stars for a trio of oddities...  

basically everything about my dining experience at the alamo square seafood grill could be summed up as just odd.  not necessarily bad.  just odd.  

oddity number one:  the special of the day was braised short ribs with choice of tuna or salmon.  what?  yes, it was their version of a surf-and-turf combo i guess.  it also came with the vegetarian risotto, which added a third, completely separate element to the plate.  nothing was bad, it just didn't really go together.  the snapper provencale was delicious, if *extremely* salty.  everything on the plate was salty in fact.  

oddity number two: the trio of creme brulees.  each was flavored and should have been delightful, but the flavors just didn't quite work.  i thought that i liked the mint brulee, but i have since decided that i didn't.  the temperatures were also all off, with cold spots throughout the little pots, resulting in strange texture.

oddity number three: the service.  i had read the reviews, so i wasn't expecting speed.  i didn't find it particularly slow, and the people were all exceptionally nice.  but the glassware was weird.  they seem to give you a tiny wine glass if you're ordering by the glass but we saw more gracious glasses on tables where bottles had been ordered.  but then i noticed that some of the water glasses were strange sizes too.  this seems like a stupid thing to fixate on, but it was very strange at the time.    also, it was really hard to get anyone's attention when we came into the restaurant.  they have free parking in a lot right around the corner (nice!) but you have to go in to ask for directions to it (it's on fulton between fillmore and webster on the north side of the road.  it's the parking lot of a large church and you can just go ahead and park there for this restaurant - no need to go in to ask for directions), and i ended up all the way in the kitchen, getting directions from the chef because he was literally the first person who noticed me. and he was IN THE KITCHEN!  

the prices are excellent and sticking with the fresh fish is a good idea.  a nice neighborhood spot, but not worth a trip across town or anything.
author: Kirsten F.

description: Wonderful hidden gem more people should know about! My boyfriend and I went on a dinner date and found the service, ambiance and food spot on.  Everything from the salad I had to the crab cake to the main course- fish- was spectacular.   The fish was fresh an only about $15-17 with rice and veggies included. I look forward to going back.
author: Emily V.

description: 3.5 stars really. Went here on Sunday prior to attending a friend's housewarming/birthday party a block away. Found parking across the street readily early at 5PM. They don't open until 5:30PM, though, but they happily seated us anyways. They only take reservations by phone, and it's an answering machine, which apparently didn't work too well for same-day reservations, but that wasn't a problem as it was still early, and maybe not so busy on a Sunday. Anyways, as for parking, there is a free lot on Fulton between Fillmore and Webster. It's a small neighborhood spot, tiny, with stylish saffron walls and brick-colored highlights, creating a comforting, cozy atmosphere. My friend and I sat in the corner spot for 2, to the left of the doorway as you enter. The comfy banquette and pillows were very appealing. And the food, what a steal! They offer a 3 course prix fixe on weekdays from 5:30 to 7:30PM and all day on Sundays! First course was a choice of cream of artichoke soup with bacon or a nicely vinaigrette-dressed green salad with artichokes, diced cucumbers, and yellow globe tomatoes. The soup was good on such a cold wintry evening, and my friend enjoyed it. I had the salad, which was a lot more interesting than it sounded, and I really enjoyed it as well. The entree was the chef's choice of beef bourguignon (containing Burgundy and often braised onions and mushrooms, parsley, thyme, and butter). There were also some Brussels sprouts and carrots. It tasted great and was a nice comfy dish. Dessert was a "Floating Island" of poached meringue in a sea of creme anglaise, centered with a mint "palm tree". The proper French name for this dessert is "Oeufs a la Neige", meaning "Eggs in the Snow". One of the original desserts of early Louisiana brought by the French, it's also sometimes called "Ile flottante". Apparently Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy ate this dessert in a movie called "The Desk Set". The wine prices here are very reasonable (and there's no corkage fee on Wednesdays), and they don't overcharge for coffee either. Our server was terrific, pleasant and personable. My friend and I had a great time, and he lives nearby, so I think this will be a great neighborhood spot for him.
author: Hao L.

description: my friends got there before the rest of us and said the calamari was the best they've had in the city. i didn't get to try it, but i would take their word especially since one is a hardcore yelp foodie. i got a sauvignon blanc, paired with a poached red snapper and it was pretty darn good! my favorite was their creme brulee dessert. it was a good size and really yummy!
author: Emy s.

description: Tonight was my second time at Alamo Sqaure Seafood Grill and once again, it was amazingly good. The last time I was there I started with the shrimp bisque which was so delicious and then had some of the best Rack of Lamb I have ever had. This time, I went for the Prix Fixe meal which is offered from 5 - 7pm daily. For $14.50 I had a green salad with a very light and flavorful dijon dressing, perfectly cooked mahi-mahi in a buerre blanc sauce, with rice and equally terrific grilled vegetables and a delicious dessert called "Floating Island". My husband ordered off the regular menu and had the same salad as me, the Country Pate appetizer and Blackened Snapper with a spicy peppercorn sauce. The food was fantastic and the bill even better: $47 for both of us. The ambiance was really nice too - cozy, dimly lit with candles at each table and very romantic overall. I'm hesitant to recommend this place, only because I don't want the secret to get out.
author: Sandi S.

description:
another night of wondering what to do for dinner cos i don't feel like making anything.  it's already 8, top chef's gonna be on in a couple hrs, man's gonna be home any minute and i've been toolin' around on yelp instead of being the domestic goddess i sometimes aspire to be.  figure we can walk or drive somewhere fairly close by, have dinner and be back in time to ogle over padma (actually i find her kinda annoying) and the top chef food.  

so we picked this place cos we've driven by it so many times and it always looked so cute and charming, like a real neighborhood gem.  boy were we disappointed.  

i'll cop to the mistake of going on a weds night when apparently they offer free corkage so it seems EVERYONE was there toting their bottle of wine like it was something to cherish and covet just to have someone open it and pour it for "free." um,  whatever.  is free corkage that big of a deal just so you can drink the wine with sub-par food?  i don't get it.  in retrospect, i find it that much more perplexing that THAT MANY people were there to partake in free corkage night just cos i really can't believe what drew them was the food and service.  i'd rather PAY the jacked up price for a bottle of wine if the food and service are going to be good.  ok, i'm getting a little off point, but b/c of the free corkage, the placed was packed and w/no reservation we had 30m wait.  fine, but w/no bar there or nearby and it being so cramped, there really wasn't much to do but awkwardly hover over other diners and get in the way of the 2 servers working the place. looking around, i noted that it didn't quite look so charming as i thought it would.  the place definitely needs a facelift/update decor-wise (grungy looking throw pillows and worn out tables do not make for shabby chic).  we preoccupied ourselves by perusing  the menu and mistakenly started to have auspicious thoughts of the evening ahead.  all the itemd sounded really tasty and they had awesome sounding specials (roasted cauliflower soup w/truffle, ahi carpaccio, grilled ono w/wh corn polenta) and the prices were rembarkably reasonable given that it was all mostly seafood.  the man who i think is the owner came by after 30m and did apologize for the long wait and offered to get us some wine.  i ordered sparkling wine.  flat.  he brought us some "snacks" in the form of their "housemade pat" on toasts.  it was pretty good so i'm starting to feel like this place might really work out.   here comes the nosedive.......

we finally got seated and i was a little skeeved cos i had to lean on this pillow that was so grimy and falling apart at the seams (literally) it looked like a museum piece from the civil war era.  determined to focus on the food, we ordered an app and entree each:

- crabcakes: tasted a little "fishy" and it was served on salad that was way overdressed; the greens wilting
- ahi carpaccio w/creme fraiche: this dish came out and visually i was pleased.  the ahi was beautiful in color and looked very fresh and the greens it came on looked a little more alive, but the dish it was all served on was WARM.  BLECCHHHHHHH
- grilled ahi tuna w/green peppercorn sauce (RECOMMENDED BY THE OWNER): came served in a way that didn't appear as if it had a seen a grill, was luke warm, no trace of green peppercorn sauce anywhere, and pathetic attempt to garnish the plate with i think were pea shoots but just thrown on the plate so they looked like grass clippings
-shellfish soup: i thought it would be something like cioppino our bouillabaise but it was more like an overcreamed, oily chowder .  the menu clearly read "shellfish" but there were hunks of fish in there and again, they tasted fishy in a bad way.  they were selling it as a soup, but it was just so fatty (they even throw this huge superfluous dollop of parsley aioli on top) i kept wondering who in their right minds could actually consume this dish in a "soup"- like fashion.

by the end of the meal, although the dessert offerings SOUNDED good, we passed cos we couldn't wait to get out of there.  the servers were so apathetic and there was so little interaction, we were convinced that neither spoke english (we found out they did when they took our credit card).  

so dinner was a bust but i'm gonna take this as a lesson learned.  eating out can be hit or miss and sadly, this was definitely a miss, but at least i won't gaze longingly anymore everytime i pass by cos now i know it kinda sucks here.

bummed i missed top chef but hooray for tivo.
author: Bird B.

description: We had dinner here last weekend at the recommendation of a colleague of my husband's who lives in the neighborhood and we loved it!  From the outside it doesn't look like much, but inside the decor is warm and inviting, candle lit.  Daily specials are written on chalk boards on the wall which reminded us of being in France.  A couple sitting next to us told us that we could order the risotto appetizer in a dinner portion, and always a sucker for good risotto, that's what I did.  My husband had the fish soup which was full of seafood and a delicious broth.  The chef started us off with an amouse bouche of white bean puree soup and fresh baked bread with the most delicious dipping oil made with fine herbes.  The best thing of all was the prices - what a great value in a city where the average dinner price seems to be $25.  Here most entrees are around $15 and could easily charge more.  But then it would lose some of it's appeal...nice ambiance, great comforting food, friendly staff, and a fantastic bargain.
author: Jen T.

description: Probably my favorite date spot in the city for price and ambiance. The food is always fresh and simple and the specials consistently offer a nice variance from the standard menu. 1/2 Price wine Mondays are always a plus especially after the start of a new week. The waiter that I always seem to have is very knowledgeable about food and wine and provides just the right amount of attitude (I hate flare). I will come back here again and again.
author: p a.

description: Another neighborhood gem, service can be a bit slow but the servers are friendly and the food is good.Try the daily specials as well as the prixe fixe menus. wednesdays are byob and no corkage fee.
author: Kevin T.

description: I ate there twice on Sunday with parties of five. The food was good and the prices are low, but we were disappointed with the service because the place was understaffed.  One waitress, however pleasant and hard working, is not enough for an entire restaurant.  Identical dishes came 10 minutes apart and I saw people waiting outside when there were empty tables inside
author: Julie M.

description:
I live very close to this restaurant, so when a friend wanted to go somewhere close, I conceded and decided to try Alamo Square Seafood Restaurant again.  I had gone a few years ago and been underwhelmed, to say the least.  Well, they definitely redeemed themselves last night!  I think they must be reading their own reviews and really working to correct things.
I have always liked the ambiance there, and if you are a fish person (which I am not necessarily) the menu is fine, but service has been a challenge.  Last night it was excellent.  Our server, a platinum blond whose name I didn't get, was wonderful.  The crab cake app was very good, though they could have brought an extra plate - knowing we were sharing.  We both had fish entrees - cooked to perfection.  Mine - the special - was to come with leeks and fingerling potatoes.  WHen I commented to the server that the fingerling potatoes seemed to be absent, she didn't get huffy or argue with me, she simply brought me a side order.  THAT is good service!  
I had previewed their website and checked out their menu - and especially their wine list - in advance.  As a sommelier, I am interested in things like that.  The wine list was above average with some bold French choices.  Unfortunately the Riesling I had hoped to try was on the website but not on the restaurant's wine list - I can forgive that.  One criticism is the dixie cup sized wine glasses - they have to go.  I asked for regular wine glasses and they provided them, albeit with a bit of an attitude (this was another waiter, not our lovely server.)   
We tried the creme brulee despite reviews reading warnings against it. Yes, the sugar crust was way too thick and sugary, but that's actually my favorite part of creme brulee, so that's ok.  The custard itself was too saucy, not custard.  They should be able to fix this - how hard is it to make a good creme brulee?
Despite little flaws, we really had a lovely, reasonable dinner.  I chalk it up to lovely atmosphere, basically excellent, well-prepared fish, and an highly skilled server.  I will now go back again as well as recommend it to others.  Did I mention it is an excellent value?
author: Sue M.

description: Great restaurant hidden away from San Francisco city center... when we arrived on Tuesday March 13th, there was only one waiter on service..no problem .. he sat us down with a smile and a "I am solo tonight -please excuse the service - will try to make it alright"... Great - he is humble! Now onto the food we had crab cakes, escargot & scallops for starters - all delicious - not under or over cooked. Next for main course we had the New york steak medium rare (yes they do non-seafood items), salmon (the days special) and grilled trout (my favorite) with a bearnaise sauce. All was cooked to perfection and arrived in a timely manner (surprising since the waiter was single handed tonight) - all of this washed down with some very reasonably priced wine. We even had place left for a little dessert which was as equally good as the previous courses. Value for money - excellent, food quality 9.5/10, ambiance - great fun to visit a local unpretentious SanFrancisco hidden gem.
author: Gary M.

description: Ok, really more like 2 1/2 stars.  Anyway, I used to love this place. My last experience here though was, shall we say, very unimpressive.  We went on Wednesday to take advantage of the free corkage and we left commenting that we would've preferred to just pay for a bottle of wine somewhere else. The service was the worst I have experienced in a long time.  While not rude, the waitress was incredibly absent minded and inattentive. Two particular examples: we both replied "yes" when she asked if we wanted ground pepper and she then proceeded to only give it to me. Second, she refilled only my wine, while leaving my friend's glass empty. With every interaction she was distracted and seemed to listen to nothing. Ok, realizing everyone has "off days", I'll move beyond the service... when I asked her what the vegetarian dish is, she told me it was the sweet corn risotto (which was the side dish that went with the fish), but that it has more veggies. When our dishes came out, I was disappointed to see I had the EXACT same risotto (in quantity and without any extra veggies) as my friend who had ordered the fish (it was his side dish!!). Needless to say, they need to step up their veggie option. Using a side dish (without even increasing the quantity or attempting to dress it up) is unacceptable. If this is how vegetarians are treated, I won't be returning.
author: SL N.

description: Everytime I go there I have the most fabulous dish! Thanks for all the delicious food and great ambiance:-) This place is awesome!
author: Lola W.

description:
My boyfriend and I stumbled upon this darling restaurant accidentally, but we have returned every time we have visitors in town or a special occasion. 
I always order the Prix Fixe, because it is such a terrific deal (and I have to get the soup and a fish dish every time I go), but the specials are also always raved about. 
I love the size of the place, it feels very intimate and is well laid out. It has a very European feel and excellent mood-setting music. 
The service is fantastic; our most recent visit with family, my brother-in-law asked the owner/head chef/waiter/all-around awesome dude how he would make a grilled cheese sandwich for himself. His answer made our mouths water (and required a little note taking due to the unheard-of cheeses) and made it all the more personal of an experience. 
We all felt very welcome, and pampered. However, my favorite thing about the restaurant remains the food - such complex flavors!
author: Meg W.

description: Great seafood prepared with French veggies and potatoes.  Nice wine list. Romantic --- definitely a date place.  Can get pricey depending what wine you order but it is fairly easy to get out of here for less than $100 or even $75 for two people.
author: David M.

description: i hand out 5s very sparingly (as in none as of this review). i really want to give it a 4.5 but that's not alowed. it's great seafood. seasonal and varied menu. charming location (good date place). (take the 22. don't try to park). i'm reviewing so i can add it to my no corkage nights list. that's right byob at no charge on Wednesdays. enjoy their good wine list on other nights.
author: cool d.

description: I visited San Fran late May of '09 with a group of people that didn't share my interest in good food, so I decided to ditch them and have a late dinner. I'm so glad I chose the Alamo Square Seafood Grill. I ate a swordfish that sat on  a fava bean puree, and loved it. I enjoyed a glass of red wine which the staff helped me pick to go with my dinner. I don't usually eat dessert, but had to have to because everything else was sooooo good! Not only was the food delicious , but for a reasonable price as well. The staff was helpful, and if you get Julia as a waitress you should feel blessed...... I'll go back for sure!
author: Carson C.

description: always wanted to try this place because it looked so quaint, but it's appeal wore off pretty quickly once inside.  the service is poor and I wasn't impressed with the waiter's recommendations (once I finally flagged him down).  I do like the neighborhoody feel of the place so maybe i'll try it again when i'm not as hungry.  could it be, that i just picked a bad fish?
author: mark l.

description: I have eaten at Alamo Square Grill numerous times in the past, but  this was my first time back after a year. My fiance and I decided to go early (5:30pm) on a Saturday evening to take advantage of the amazingly affordable prix fixe. i am happy to report Alamo Square Grill is as good as ever. I had the red snapper prix fixe and my partner ordered a crab cake and the seafood stew. Everything was savory and delicious. The maitre d' steered us to a red Chilean Malbec (available by the glass) that was earthy and fruity good. We finished with tirami su and a small glass of luscious port. Being Italian I am a bit of a tirami su connoisseur. Having the right commingling of sweet ladyfinger, tart espresso and rich fresh-whipped mascapone, the desert easily met my standards.
author: rosemary p.

description: Can't beat the price of early dining 3 course Prix Fixe (everyday 5:30-7pm). Very friendly/ interesting chef, he will come out chat with you if not too busy. Affordable price plus you get to choose the way you want exactly...type of fishes, way of prepared, and sauce. Even though the Prix Fixe price gone up 2 dollars, it still way worth it. The only tiny problem I have is I like the butter/ oil my Escargots bathing in a little bit saltier. I can always add salt myself though.
author: G T.

description: It's no Gary Danko's but they know their fish. My crab stuffed trout with a cream sauce was DELICIOUS. Service was casual and quick. This is a great local find for me...12 minutes walk...
author: Gina S.

description: The five of us came for 6 pm dinner.  We were hoping to try the prix fixe dinner for $ 15.  The prix fixe dinner was set for one kind of fish and set sauce which differs from my understanding of the reading of the menu.  Two of us opt for the prix fixe dinner and the rest of us order off the regular menu.  The soup ordered was warm and we wish it was hotter.  We all ordered Ahi Tuna or Grilled Salmon, the fish was fresh and excellent.  The service staff was professional, but we felt they were one short for the night.  The wait for dessert was way too long (20 mins).  The apple tart was the best of desserts for that night.  The prix fixe dessert was just average and the chocolate pudding bread was not what I expected.  The $ 30 bottle of white wine was a twist open cap which I found tacky for that price.
author: Food Sage W.

description: After 2 hours of a crazy critical mass ride through SF, we couldn't have been hungrier.  Riding bikes back to a friend's house, recognizing the hunger pains in our stomach, we saw a dimly lit red glow coming from what appeared to be the only restaurant for a few blocks. Friday night at 7:45 pm we were sat quickly, right before the crowd came in, and served promptly.  So enticed by the appetizers, we skipped over the entrees and dug into steamed mussels, a trout salad, calamari, and crab cakes.  Each dish delicious and reasonably priced, especially for seafood.
author: Beth S.

description: So delicious.  We ordered two soups to go-- the soup of the day (potato fennel) and a fish soup loaded with chunks of fish, mussels and shrimp.  Polite and accommodating over the phone.  We just might eat there one day.
author: Daniel M.
